story: British singer Tom Odell claimed a German man quizzed him in the toilets of a service station after the UK voted for Brexit.The artist claimed he was on tour when a German man asked him what he was doing in the country.Speaking on talkRADIO, the singer appeared shocked by the remark but took it well.He said: &ldquoIt&rsquos really funny. The day we Brexited we flew to Germany.                George&rsquos Osborne Project Fear campaign MOCKED on BBC Newsnight                &lsquoWe messed up before Brexit vote&rsquo - George Osborne makes admission &ldquoI went to the toilet in some service station, we were doing a show in Germany.&ldquoI was having a wee and this German guy looked over to me and he goes &lsquowhat are you doing here&rsquo.&ldquoI was like &lsquofair enough, fair enough&rsquo.Britain voted to cut ties with the European Union on June 23 in 2016, in the same month Odell released his second studio album.Brexit news: Tom Odell reveals being in Germany on the day of the Brexit vote (Image: TALKRADIO)Negotiations between Britain and the EU remain in&nbspa stalemate&nbspwith EU leaders pushing back a November summit until &ldquodecisive progress has been made in discussions.Speaking last week, Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab warned the European Union about a no deal, should they refuse to budge in negotiations.He said: &ldquoThere certainly is a risk of no deal especially if the EU engage in a deliberately intransigent approach.Speaking during a meeting in Oslo on Tuesday,&nbspMrs&nbspMay told leaders of countries including Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia, Denmark, Finland, Iceland and Sweden she was looking to secure a good Brexit deal with the EU after Brexit.She said: Yes the UK is leaving the EU, we are not leaving Europe, and we will continue to have, we want to continue to have, a good relationship with the 27 countries remaining in the EU.We are working for a good deal to establish those relationships and that future partnership, but we also want to continue to have good bilateral relations but also work in different combinations of countries as well.

title: Brexit news eu workers immigration news caroline nokes
story: Brexit news: Caroline Nokes said firms will be forced to check EU workers  (Image: PA )Caroline Nokes made the revelation as she also admitted it would be an &ldquoalmost impossible job for employers to know which EU citizens of their staff can remain in the country after the UK&rsquos exit.The government wants the estimated 3.5 million EU citizens in Britain to apply for settled status so that they can continue to live and work here but that will not happen by the time the UK is due to leave the bloc next March.Ms Nokes told firms they would be expected to carry out &ldquoadequately rigorous checks but gave no further clarity on what the government would expect of a business to ensure workers are in the UK legitimately.The immigrations minister came under pressure after she said EU citizens would have to &ldquoevidence their right to work in the UK after March 29 2019.                Japan royal wedding PICTURES: Stunning photos of princess who has g...                Brexit shock poll: Most Britons do NOT fear leaving EU with NO-DEALShe said: &ldquoIf somebody has been through the settled status scheme they would be able to evidence that.&ldquoIf somebody hasn&rsquot been here prior to the end of March next year, employers will have to make sure they go through adequately rigorous checks to evidence somebody&rsquos right to work.Committee members raised concerns that with just five months to go before the nation exits the bloc, a registration process is yet to be rolled out.This forced Ms Nokes to acknowledge employers may struggle to establish whether a prospective EU worker is a long-term resident if they have not yet obtained the status that confirms their right to live and work in the UK.Brexit news: Caroline Nokes was forced to admit it would be 'almost impossible'  (Image: REUTERS )She said: &ldquoIt would pose a challenge to government and indeed employers in differentiating between those two groups of people.In a difficult evidence session at the home affairs select committee, Ms Nokes was repeatedly asked what the checks would be.She offered to clear up any confusion in a letter to the committee but denied the future system is unworkable.Ms Nokes said: You are absolutely right to point out that somebody who has been here for ten years and has simply not yet been through the scheme, it will be almost impossible for an employer to differentiate between them and somebody who is a new arrival.                China SPY PLANE enters NO-fly zone - South Korea forced to scramble...She insisted the approach would be pragmatic and the early enforcement regime would not be overly rigorous.Ms Nokes added: We are quite clear that this is absolutely one of the conundrums employers will face - that people who have rights under the settled status scheme but haven't yet gone through the process to evidence that.The Tory minister said an immigration bill would &ldquoturn off free movement once Brexit happened and remove the automatic right of EU nationals to live and work in Britain.She said in the event of the UK crashing out of Brussels without a deal immigration controls would apply to EU citizens arriving in Britain next year.Under the Government's proposed settlement scheme, EU migrants who have been in the UK for five years by the end of 2020 can apply for settled status, meaning they are free to go on living and working in the UK indefinitely.Those who have arrived by December 31 2020 but do not have five years' residence can seek to stay until they have, at which point they can seek settled status.EU citizens who arrive in the implementation period, which starts after the official exit date in March, will face no new curbs on living and working in the UK but will be required to register if they intend to stay for longer than three months.The settlement scheme is currently being trialled and will be fully operational next year.It is anticipated the total number of applications could run to more than 3.5 million.Ms Nokes told the committee: It is going to be an enormous challenge for both employers and EU citizens who do have the right to work to make sure we get them through the scheme as efficiently as we possibly can.Her evidence sparked claims the Government's approach to Brexit risks a repeat of the Windrush scandal.Labour MP David Lammy tweeted: &ldquoLet me get this straight. @ukhomeoffice says EU citizens will have to prove their right to work in the UK after March next year - but it's 5 months away and the registration process has not been rolled out.&ldquoWe're on course for another Home Office scandal on the scale of Windrush.Liberal Democrat Home Affairs spokesman Sir Ed Davey added: Millions of EU citizens in the UK have been living under a cloud of uncertainty for more than two years.Far from clearing up that uncertainty today, the Immigration Minister made it worse.&nbsp

story: Russian state media initially reported there was no damage to the Kuznetsov when the dock sank into the icy sea but a report by 360TV channel later claimed there has been unspecified damage to Russian flagship &ldquoafter two dock tower cranes collapsed.The dock&rsquos ballast tanks were overloaded with water after a power cut while repairs were being carried out on the Kuznetsov.The sunken dock is one of the largest in the world - and crucial to the repairs of large naval surface ships and submarines in Mr Putin&rsquos battle fleet.Zvezdochka shipyard spokesman Yevgeny Gladyshev said: &ldquoDespite an emergency, the Admiral Kuznetsov was floated. Russia shows off devastating warship ready to carry out airstrikes                Amateur hour Russian missile launch is caught on cameraAs far as we know the circumstances now, the accident happened as Admiral Kuznetsov carrier was launched into the water. I can&rsquot say if the dock was damaged.Sources said the floating dock had already sunk completely.The 360TV report stated: &ldquoRussia's only aircraft carrier Admiral Kuznetsov has been damaged after two dock tower cranes collapsed.The Admiral Kuznetsov - commissioned in 1990 - is undergoing a refit begun in July.&nbspIt has been involved in naval convoys passing the British coast.Admiral Kuznetsov on the floating dock in Murmansk (Image: REUTERS)Admiral Kuznetsov sails through the English Channel near Dover in October 2016 (Image: )Admiral Kuznetsov on patrol off the Syrian coast (Image: )The accident appears to be a major set back for the Russian military machine since the dock is seen as the only one suitable for the aircraft carrier and the Pyotr Velikiy Kirov-class battlecruiser.An eye-witness told Murmansky Vestnik newspaper: &ldquoThe dock sank partially at first, then it broke and went underwater completely, now even its machine tower is not visible.Four people were taken to hospitals in Rogalyovo and Murmansk where they were treated for hypothermia.One person is reported to have suffered stomach injuries.                NEW COLD WAR: Russian aggression is a return to the bad old days, s...Viktor Rogalev, Head of the Murmansk Territorial Disaster Medicine Centre, said that one of the workers was in a &ldquograve condition.Three other men were in a &ldquomoderately bad state after being plucked from the icy waters of Kola Bay.The 330-metre-long and 76-metre-wide floating dry dock was built in 1980 in Sweden for the Soviet Navy, and has a capacity of up to 80,000 tons.It was designed specifically for the repair of the former Soviet Union&rsquos large ships and submarines.Additional reporting by Will Stewart

title: EU news Jean Claude Juncker clocks change daylight saving 2019 latest
story: Opposition grows for Jean-Claude Juncker plans to abolish EU clock changes in 2019 (Image: )Top eurocrat Jean-Claude Juncker&rsquos bid to abolish seasonal clock changes within the EU were branded unrealistic by transport ministers in the first sign of public descent for the plans.The European Commission President&rsquos signature policy, which is mainly backed by Germany, would have seen Europe stop changing its clocks in October 2019, creating a permanent summer or winter time.But a number of sceptical EU member states have criticised the proposed timeline, insisting the change will leave businesses and citizens unprepared for the huge policy shift.Austrian transport minister Norbert Hofer, who hosted his 27 EU counterparts in Graz, questioned whether Mr Juncker&rsquos rushed through policy would receive the support of a majority of member states.Mr Hofer said: &ldquoIf we aim to do this in 2019, as the European Commission suggested, this will not be supported by the majority of member states.He, instead, suggested Brussels&rsquo powerful executive hold off on their plans and look at the summer of 2021 for its potential implementation.Britain, Sweden and Poland are amongst the most vocal of the member states, who are currently opposed to Mr Juncker&rsquos plans.Mr Hofer said: &ldquoThree countries were sceptical and one was concerned that we could end up with a patchwork of different times zones.                UK could SCRAP clock change from 2019 in DRASTIC plan proposed by EU                EU pushes on with talks to scrap daylight saving timeAirlines were amongst the major businesses who had raised their own questions about abolishing the twice-yearly clock change.They would need more time to make necessary technical preparations, according to Mr Hofer.&ldquoFor example, the airline industry tells us they need at least 18 months to prepare, he said.Brexit was also mentioned as the possibility of a time border being created between Northern Ireland and Great Britain remains given the uncertainty surrounding negotiations on Britain&rsquos EU departure.&ldquoWe must also be careful that we don&rsquot end up with a patchwork of time zones, Mr Hofer added.Luxembourg&rsquos transport minister Fancois Bausch said it would be a &ldquocatastrophe for his country to be locked in a different timezone from Belgium, France and Germany.This is because half of Luxembourg&rsquos workforce commute into the country and require a harmonised system with its neighbours, according to Mr Bausch.Danish transport minister Ole Birk Olesen said his country would require a full public debate and therefore cannot comply with the 2019 timetable.He said: &ldquoThere is not much awareness about the fact that it will have costs whatever we choose.Last month, Mr Juncker announced the Commission would press on with its plans after an EU-wide poll found 84 percent of the 4.6 million participants supported abolishing the twice-yearly clock change.But the poll&rsquos results were somewhat skewed because they represented less than one percent of the EU&rsquos population and most respondents were from Germany.

title: Angela Merkel resigns news exit resignation latest Germany
story: Angela Merkel has desperately tried to reassert her authority after her resignation (Image: Getty)Germany&rsquos strong-woman, who has been in power for 13 years, saw her authority crumble after her party suffered painful losses in a crunch regional election over the weekend.Ms Merkel announced on Monday she would not seek re-election as leader of the centre-right CDU party and also confirmed she would step down as Chancellor of Germany after 2021.Since then, political commentators have strongly criticised Ms Merkel and claimed her resignation essentially leaves her sitting as a lame duck.European Studies Professor Stephen Auer said her exit came &ldquotoo little too late and that she has now become a &ldquoliability.                Angela Merkel replacement odds: Who will replace Angela Merkel?In a bid to reassert her authority, the Germany leader suggested her resignation could actually work in her favour.Speaking at a news conference alongside Egypt&rsquos President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi during a summit on Africa in Berlin, Ms Merkel said: &ldquoI don't believe that anything will change about the negotiating position in international negotiations.&ldquoOne can even say I have more time to concentrate on my tasks as the head of government.Echoing the Chancellor&rsquos words, member of CSU conservative party Manfred Weber, told broadcaster ZDF that Ms Merkel could now &ldquolead without the pressure.Speaking at a news conference Ms Merkel said she doesn't believe anything will change (Image: Getty)He said: &ldquoThere&rsquos also a chance that she can lead without the pressure that all her decisions have to be popular.&ldquoWe must have the courage again to look beyond the vagaries of our daily politics and to be a bit visionary because the next years and decades will not be pleasant for our company.However, Mr Weber's seems to be an unpopular opinion as Oliver Rakau, a chief German economist at Oxford Economics, was recently asked in an interview with CNBC how likely he thought it was that the Chancellor would stay until 2021.In response, he said: &ldquoPersonally, I do not think it&rsquos as likely as she&rsquos probably hoping.                Brexiteer MP warns Merkel quitting gives EU further scope to punish UK                Merkel could replace Juncker to 'COMPLETE German DOMINATION of Europe' Oliver Rakau, a chief German economist, said Ms Merkel will stand down before 2021 (Image: Getty)&ldquoBut it&rsquos really the only thing she could say in the given circumstances.&ldquoMy personal baseline case is that once we know who her successor is as the head of the CDU, her party, it&rsquos likely that person will eventually take over as Chancellor.Either in a new form coalition after new elections.But the cynic added it doesn&rsquot look likely that there will be elections any time soon.He continued: &ldquoPersonally, I think there&rsquos not a big appetite in German politics for new elections at least right now because the two main parties, CUD as well as the Social Democrats, are polling very weakly.&ldquoSo I think they will, for now, just try to limp on.

title: prince harry meghan markle royal tour australia new zealand
story: The  day trip was packed with engagements, with the Invictus Games taking centre stage.The destination for the Duke and Duchess of Sussexs first official trip as husband and we mimicked Harrys parents first overseas tour, as they visited Australia in , shortly after their own wedding.The Sussexes touched down in Australia on October , shortly before news of Meghans pregnancy hit the headlines across the globe.Their tour officially kicked off on Tuesday , when the Duke climbed Sydney Harbour Bridge to raise the Invictus Games’ flag.The newlyweds attended the Opening Ceremony, before watching the sailing, cycling and wheelchair basketball events.On their first day they also visited Admiralty House, the official Sydney residence of the Governor-General of Australia, Sir Peter Cosgrove.The property boasted spectacular views across Sydney Harbour, home to the iconic Sydney Opera House.Representatives from each of the  countries taking part in the Invictus Games were present.The couple visited the world-famous Taronga Zoo where they met two koalas and their joeys.Royals fans will remember it as the same zoo where Prince George delighted the world as he joyfully interacted with a bilby named after him during the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge’s  tour.Day  saw the couple head km outside of Sydney to Dubbo to shine a spotlight on problems wrought by drought in the area.The Duke and Duchess then opened the Taronga Institute of Science and Learning, and visited the laboratory to meet conservation scientists working to reduce illegal wildle trafficking.On the next leg, the pair landed in Fiji where they received a traditional welcome similar to the one the Queen and Duke of Edinburgh received during their own Royal tour of .Meghan then attended Suva market without her husband to meet female vendors, although after a whisper to one of her security aides left very promptly, supposedly due to concerns about overcrowding and humid temperatures.October October October October October October October October October October October October October October November Moving on to Tonga, the royals were greeted at the airport by Her Royal Highness The Princess Angelika Latufuipeka.The evening consisted of a private audience with His Majesty King Tupou VI and Queen Nanasipauʻu, followed by an official reception and dinner and traditional Tongan entertainment.Back in Sydney the pair attended the Invictus Games closing ceremony and both made speeches.On October , Harry and Meghan flew to New Zealand to start the final leg of their tour.The couple were welcomed with a traditional ceremony on the lawns of Government House – the residence of the Governor-General to New Zealand Dame Patsy Reddy.They watched a haka performance with maori elders and enjoyed a forest trail walk through Abel Tasman National Park.Meghan Markle then proceeded to beat Prince Harry in a traditional welly wanging competition before the couple attended a reception hosted by Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern at the Auckland War Memorial Museum.During the final days of the tour, their Royal Highnesses visited the North Shore to dedicate a  hectare area of native bush to The Queen’s Commonwealth Canopy.The couple will head home to the UK on  November.

title: philip hammond theresea may budget
story: I know for many, the past few years haven’t been easy. But I’m happy to tell Sun on Sunday readers that their hard work is paying off.Our jobs market has defied many of the naysayers.Near record numbers of people have a job and unemployment has fallen in every region across the country.There are more than .million additional people in work since .While this is a huge achievement, sometimes it’s easy to forget that behind these numbers are thousands of people up and down our country who are now better able to provide for their families.They can get up every morning knowing they have the security that only a job can bring.And what’s more, they are being rewarded with a pay rise — this month’s figures show the strongest wage growth in almost a decade.Contrary to myths peddled by the opposition, it’s people at the bottom of the pay scale who have benefited most.The lowest earners working full-time have seen the fastest rise in pay thanks to our National Living Wage and the proportion of low-paid jobs is at a record low.Tomorrow I will deliver my Budget, where I will show how our careful focus on fixing the economy is bearing fruit.Thanks to the balanced approach we have taken — getting our debt falling, while keeping taxes low — and the hard work of the people of the UK, I will be able to set out how we will be investing in our future.Much of the talk surrounding Budgets is often technical. Many, many experts and commentators will have their own take on how the economy is doing.While this is, of course, important, what most ordinary people really care about is how the Budget will improve their day-to-day lives.And one of the issues which I know Sun on Sunday readers care a lot about is transport. With a thousand more people moving into work every day, it’s important that we help to get them there on time.Many of you preparing to start the working week tomorrow will know the frustration of having your journey to work ruined by delays caused by poorly maintained roads. Or of having your car or van damaged by potholes.This isn’t just a bad way to start the day, it’s bad for businesses large and small, and it can be really damaging to the wider economy as well.It’s estimated that congestion costs UK households more than £billion every year. That’s why tomorrow I will announce a bumper £billion investment in our country’s transport network — including a new £.billion fund ring-fencing vehicle excise duty raised in England for spending on our roads.As a former Transport Secretary, I know that these are the arteries that keep our country alive – and they need taking care of. Thirty-two years ago tomorrow, Margaret Thatcher officially opened the final stretch of the M.While few would claim to love this motorway, it’s easy to forget what a landmark moment this was for our country’s transport infrastructure. Three decades later, I am committed to honouring that legacy.And as important as our major roads are, smaller local roads are just as vital to our everyday lives.That’s why I will also announce tomorrow £million of immediate cash for councils to maintain and improve local roads — fixing potholes, repairing damaged roads and keeping bridges safe and open.A further £million on top of that will help improve local junctions, allowing better access to workplaces, high streets and other community facilities.This is also part of our commitment to bridging the gap between our regions. Those in rural parts of the country should have the same chances to get on in le and not have poor transport connections limiting their potential.The funding will help make journeys quicker and easier, while boosting productivity and improving access.And because I know that not everyone drives, I will also invest in local transport projects which could include new bus, tram and cycling routes.And I will also look to the future by investing in next-generation methods of transport, which could potentially include self-driving shuttle services.Not only could this revolutionise our transport network, it will also help us become a global leader developing future technologies.And finally, as I earlier announced with the Prime Minister, I am happy to confirm we will also be freezing fuel duty, for the ninth year in a row.This will keep the cost of fuel down for millions of drivers across the UK — saving people around £million this year alone.These measures are only possible due to our careful management of the economy over the past few years — and the hard work of the British people.This country has a bright future ahead, and — thanks to this vital investment package — the journey there just got a bit smoother.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: chancellors 13bn budget priti patel
story: The Chancellor is set to announce an unexpected £ billion annual windfall in this week’s budget, which means he won’t have to take away more of what you earn and put up your taxes to fund the extra £ billion a year that has been promised for the NHS by .This is good news for taxpayers and also for our economy, as this is the largest annual change in borrowing forecasts since this data was first produced in  when Margaret Thatcher was Prime Minister.And there’s a reason for this windfall. It shows the strength and resilience of the UK economy alongside the efforts and hard work of families and households up and down the country.In conventional times voters might rightly expect the result of this to be lower taxes , more investment in our public services or to see progress in us paying off the ever ballooning national debt.Instead the Government is preparing to blow this cash - your money - by giving into even more of the EU’s demands.Until last week, Britain expected a  month “transition” or “implementation” period after we formally leave the EU next year on March , .Then, late last week the Government shocked everyone by proposing that we stay in the EU longer than we were originally told and that we extend the so called ‘negotiating period’ to leave the EU.Worse still, on Monday in the House of Commons, we were told that this transition period might last until June  – that’s six years after the referendum result. Whatever happened to Brexit means Brexit On top of our extended membership of the EU, we can expect a bill from the EU! That’s right more of your money with an extra price tag of approximately £ billion each year in contributions to the EU.The Treasury has budgeted for this until the end of  but for each year after , the cost will be as high as £ billion because we will have lost the £. billion a year rebate which was famously secured and successfully negotiated in  by Margaret Thatcher when she demanded our money back from the EU.The British people are once again being treated like fools. What we are now witnessing is a blatant attempt to keep Britain in the EU while Brussels continues to raid the pockets of British taxpayers.This must end and the Government should invoke the great Thatcherite spirit of Fontainebleau and say No, No, No to Brussels. Because pumping our money into an undemocratic and unaccountable system two years after Britain voted to leave the EU is simply not right or acceptable. It makes a mockery of our democracy and is an insult to the British public.It is our money and that money should be handed back to the people and communities across the UK to invest in our domestic priorities.It could help people across Britain– especially the least well off – by giving them back more of the money that they earn by cutting their taxes.For example,we cut the basic rate of income tax by a penny, that would cost us £ billion.By increasing the personal allowance by a £,, many more of the poorest paid households would be taken out of tax altogether, that’d cost us £. billion. Andwe cut beer and cider duty by  pence, that would cost us £. billion.So by easing the tax burden for the lowest paid and doing our bit to save British pubs from closing, we’d have invested £ billion into longer term economic growth in our economy.And with the other £ billion  How about supporting the millions of families who want to own their own home by cutting stamp duty for homeowners, we can again help the least well off and give them a hand up and support them in their aspirations to own their home.We could also take more first time buyers out of paying stamp duty altogether  If we raised the starting threshold of £, to £,, this would cost the Treasury £. billion.Then there’s the VAT we pay on domestic gas and electricity. The  per cent VAT charge on domestic fuel and power raised around £. billion in  . If we got rid of this we would make fuel cheaper and families would have a little extra left over in their monthly pay packets.What about the VAT charged on sanitary products for women  This should end now and not when we leave the EU s the Government previously promised, especially as leaving the EU will take longer than we were previously promised. VAT receipts from the sale of sanitary products costs approximately £. billion a year but importantly this one VAT cut that would unite women across the country.I could go on. There are so many important domestic key services and priorities to invest in.To govern is to choose and the choice being made our Government is to spend your money on an expensive and everlasting EU membership.And all this comes on top of the ridiculous capitulation where we have agreed to the EU’s demands to hand over a £ billion pay cheque for absolutely nothing in .Britain needs once again to have a long term economic plan that puts our national interest first.Let’s start standing up for Britain by investing in people, businesses and communities rather than the unelected and unaccountable bureaucrats of the European Union.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says budget just start
story: When we put them forward next March we will be an independent nation again.Even Philip Hammond will need to crack a smile.Because as we approach Brexit, the people of this country will want to hear details about the enormous benefits of our long, hard battle to finally wrest control from the EU.They will want to be told about lower taxes, cheaper goods and the biggest boost for business in our nation’s history.The Chancellor’s £billion spending proposals on social care and our roads in tomorrow’s budget are, of course, welcome.But they do not come near enough to the sort of good news we expect to hear on March .We would prefer Mr Hammond to tell us how he is going to put more money in people’s pockets.After all, what is the point of the Tories,they don’t stand for people keeping hold of more of their hard-earned cash We would also like the Chancellor to show his plans to kickstart Britain’s productivity, innovation and growth, across every corner of the country.Slashing business taxes will help private companies grow, whether big outfits or hard-working Sun on Sunday readers setting up small firms.We have the fourth-lowest home-ownership rate in the EU. If the Tories don’t address this, voters will punish them.Their long-term success depends on creating and sustaining a property-owning democracy.Once we are unshackled from Brussels, the whole world will open up for us.And we will have opportunity to properly prosper as an independent nation once again.Filling in our potholes is all well and good, but the Government must focus on laying the foundations to make sure Britain is on the road to a GREAT future.SOME good Brexit advice for the PM.Don’t be a pushover, walk in like you mean business and be prepared to wait for the best deal.But this guidance doesn’t come from the IMF, the BoE or even the IoD.It’s courtesy of a South London businessman: Mr Del Boy Trotter of Peckham.Theresa May could do worse than read his Sun column.Mais oui! story: In a victory for The Sun, Philip Hammond will today announce a commemorative Brexit p coin, available from March , , to mark the moment we leave the EU.It will have the Queen’s head on one side and the phrase “Friendship with all nations” on the other — exactly the type of positive, outward-looking message we want to send.Despite the Remain naysayers’ claims, Britain remains a top global financial, diplomatic and military power.Unshackled from the EU, we will boom as a global business hub by developing new relationships.Despite the Government’s commemorative move, the Royal Mail refuses to release a Brexit stamp, claiming our exit will not be “an important anniversary”. What a load of codswallop!They thought it was appropriate to issue stamps commemorating TV show Game Of Thrones and for when we joined the EEC in  and the Single Market in  . . .Royal Mail bosses clearly detest the democratic decision to leave the EU.But for them to pretend Brexit is not a genuinely signicant historical moment is first-class buffoonery.IT has been a sad weekend in football.Immensely popular Leicester City owner Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha died alongside four others in a helicopter crash on Saturday night.The Thai billionaire bankrolled their  title-winning season, one of the beautul game’s greatest fairytales.The immense outpouring of grief from Foxes supporters showed how loved he was, while fans from teams as far afield as Inter Milan paid their respects alongside them on what is being described as the “darkest day” in Leicester’s history.RIP, Vichai.Meanwhile, former England star and ex-gaffer Glenn Hoddle is recovering in hospital after collapsing on TV.The reaction of footie fans and stars he played alongside, against and managed shows how well regarded he is.Get well soon, Glenn.THE proposed reform of non-disclosure agreementsis welcome.These contracts serve a purpose in some fields, such as business, where confidentiality is often necessary.But after the “Sir” Philip Green scandal last week, it is clear to all that they are being grossly misused.NDAs were not created so that the rich and powerful could gag people who make serious accusations against them.In a free society, people must always be able to blow the whistle.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The Chancellor revealed in his his Budget that he will put extra funding into the welfare system to help those struggling.Mr Hammond said today that he would increase the work allowances in Universal Credit by £, - allowing millions of people to earn £ more automatically from next April.. million households are set to benefit from the change, which are applicablea claimant or a partner has responsibility for a child or limits capacity for work.And he will pump £billion into the new system overall for the next five years to help those going onto the flagship programme get eased in.Other measures will cost him £.billion - including reducing debts for those on benefits, and giving them more upfront before switching over.The Sun has called for the Chancellor to plug the gap in the flagship benefits system, which emerged after George Osborne cut the work allowance back when he was in charge.But critics are saying this cash doesnt go far enough - think tanks said around £billion was needed to reverse all the gaps in the system.The small print said:Torsten Bell, Director of the Resolution Foundation said of todays news: The Chancellor has also delivered a welcome boost to families on Universal Credit worth £ a year. This will mean that the government’s flagship welfare reform is now more generous than the benefit system that it is replacing.While today’s reforms certainly won’t end all the problems some recipients have faced with Universal Credit, they should ease the rollout in the months and years ahead.But Lib Dem MP Stephen Lloyd said it wouldnt cover all the costs of the Osborne cuts., and there were still issues with the new system.He raged: UC’s serious design flaws were also not addressed, from long waiting times that are pushing people into indebtedness, to problems in how landlords are paid housing benefit.The pain caused by the roll-out of UC is not over yet.Today we revealed how a single mum is at risk of homelessness after going on to the new system - and isnt eligible for help with her mortgage debt payments.Tina Davidson says she feels tossed aside by the system and has had to put the house shes lived in for  years up for sale to pay off debts.The new system is designed to try and get more Brits into work and less reliant on the welfare system, but its been beset with problems.Many say its pushing them into debt as the wait for the first payment is at least five weeks.Others say they were driven to payday loans and even prostitution to try and make ends meet.Ministers say they are constantly trying to fix the systems problems as they go along - and the new system is much less complicated than the old one.It was reported earlier this month that ministers are planning moves to slow down the roll out to try and fix some of the issues.They can take out emergency loans, but have to start paying them back immediately so they get deducted from their benefits.Highlights of todays Budget include:

title: latest telethon shows us once and for all that c4s just a load of cake and balls
story: You watch BBC’s Children In Need, you’re getting Clare Balding, Doctor Who and dancers, whether you like it or not.ITV  It’d take sniper fire or a dinner setting next to Sir Phillip Green before Cowell was a no-show.Channel , though Apart from a bit of a secondhand cake-baking and Gogglebox, I was drawing a blank before Friday night.So it was with a mix of fascination and dread that I tuned into Stand Up To Cancer. A seven-hour slog live from Westminster City Hall, presented by Adam Hills, Maya Jama and the network’s spare part Alan Carr, who set the tone for most of what followed interviewing Foxy from SAS: Who Dares Wins.“It’s been announced you’ve got a new Stand Up To Cancer series starting next year. Tell us about it.”“I can’t.”“Give us some names.”“I can’t.”No sooner had we written that one off than it become apparent there was no Bake Off special either — just a promo for a show that will be screened months from now. No matter, though. With its lofty public-serving hat on, Adam Hills faithfully promised Channel  would “educate, entertain and inspire” us for the remainder of the evening, which must have looked quite good written down.In practice The first thing to say about Stand Up To Cancer is that it featured some of the most beautul and affecting films you’ll see on a telethon.They needed to be, as well, ’cos you don’t have to have watched the event to know it contained a lot of feeble stunts and sketches.I also could have lived without Adam Hills carrying out a threat to have his pubic hair waxed, live, once the total reached £million, and the educational segment, with Katherine Ryan and Chris O’Dowd, which was sunk the moment he announced: “We’re goingto put the humour in tumour.”Tellingly, there was also a fair bit of non-network talent involved, including James Corden.I’ll not dwell, though, on what Channel ’s Twitter feed did to the Carpool Karaoke segment, where Michael Buble talked about his son’s illness, except to say it was one of those productions where the left hand wasn’t talking to the right.So when Chris O’Dowd was moved to tears talking about the cancer films, the studio audience was guffawing loudly at Alan Carr manoeuvring himself into background position in a Prue Leith wig.By a process of elimination and production gaffs, though, it became apparent the centre of Channel ’s entire universe now is Gogglebox, which had created an all-star version with Louis Tomlinson, Danny Dyer and daughter Dani for the occasion.They missed a trick, frankly, by not capturing Louis falling asleep to The X Factor. But it was still riotously funny watching the regulars pick apart Naked Attraction, with the choicest comment being: “That one looks like Homer Simpson’s mouth.”This was not the sound of people laughing with the channel, though. They were laughing at it.A network that was once known for being brave and innovative is now far more readily associated with a genital parade, third-rate reality shows and cakes than anything in the way of ground-breaking drama or comedy.In fact, the only two genuinely funny people on its payroll are probably Jimmy Carr and Sean Lock, who had to make way, at Stand Up To Cancer, for box-ticking randoms like Mo Gilligan, who was served this testicular curve-ball by Maya Jama.“Do you have a special name for your balls, by any chance ”He does.The Big Narstie Show.So there I was, gently drting off as Darcey Bussell went through the technical motions on Strictly. “The control in the rise and fall. Strong in the two-three.”When, unless I’m imagining it, she told Sean Walsh: “You have to smooth it out and iron it out, so it isn’t jerking off or skippy.”Suddenly I was all ears for the show’s Halloween special – an event which, for three good reasons, is usually my least favourite of the run.Firstly, Tess always expects a laugh for referring to it as a “spook-tacular”. Secondly, someone does The ****ing Timewarp. And thirdly, the worst danceris forced to jig around to The Monster Mash.We got it all, on Saturday night, of course, yet somehow it didn’t feel quite such an endurance as normal.This may have been partly down to Ashley Roberts and Faye Tozer, who both danced like dreams, but it definitely owed something to the presence of Sean, who’s added real jeopardy to proceedings andactual comedy.His snog with Katya has made sense of a dreadful line-up and the BBC should be eternally grateful to The Sun and the photographer for capturing the moment.So although the handbag-clutchers will no doubt disagree, I was genuinely sad to see him voted off and probably back to the ex-girlfriend, where, in the words of Darcey Bussell, he’ll have to “smooth it out and iron it out” or he’ll end up, you know . . . “skippy”.Sandra Oh’s performance in Killing Eve. Aberdeen clinically dispatching some Glasgow-based team - in the Betfred Cup semi-final on Sunday.Nabhaan Rizwan heading towards the awards zone with BBC’s Informer, the best show currently on television.And the one positive to emerge from Luisa Omielan’s Politics For Bitches, which was the response from an estate agent when the “comedian” asked him what she’d have to do to afford a multi-million-pound mansion in London’s Little Venice.“Be funnier.”Since the last quarterly update, EastEnders has split into two distinct and very contrasting shows. There’s a brutal, gripping and addictive version set in Mick Carter’s prison wing, which seemed to have vanished into thin air a couple of weeks ago.And there’s the other, more familiar EastEnders we’re stuck with full-time now. A loud, grim and unforgiving place where Hayley Slater cannot decide between calling her unborn baby Stacey, in tribute to her cousin Jean, as a nod to the mad auntie, or Lee Marvin in honour of Big Mo.Worse still, though, is -year-old Keanu’s ongoing, very energetic affair with mighty Sharon Mitchell, , who’s attempted to cover the truth by claiming he’s her “personal trainer”. .“I gave him his job back,” she claimed, “He’s been getting me in shape.” The shape of what, though, is the question  An oval  A rhomboid Guy the Gorilla’s statue at London zoo An unflattering image, admittedly, but it’s nothing compared to the mental one Dot Cotton conjured up on Tuesday night, with readers of a fragile disposition advised to look away now: “Don’t play the innocent with me, Robbie Jackson. I know you’ve been fingering my Garibaldis.”See. I did warn you.This week’s winner is camp Frank, from The Apprentice, and US outlaw Jesse James.Sent in by Peter Budgen, via email. title: philip hammond budget cash public money
story: Philip Hammond spoke yesterday for more than an hour. There were announcements on schools funding, defence, moving “from disposable to reusable cups across all beverage types” — even a tax break for public loos. More money for social care and Universal Credit.Shopkeepers will breathe a sigh of relief at a hefty cut to business rates.There were hints of more money for the police. Sun readers will also welcome the tax freezes on beer, spirits, cider and short-haul flights.But the big bucks — some £.billion of the £.billion extra the Government expects to spend come - — went to the NHS, fulfilling the Prime Minister’s summer promise to increase spending as a th birthday present to a health service creaking under the strain of an ageing population.The question, of course, was how the Chancellor was going to pay for it.Before the Budget, all sorts of grim possibilities had been floated.Extra taxes on white-van men, lower- ing the VAT threshold and tightening the rules about National Insurance contributions. Taxes on plastic cups . Taxes on pretty much anything, really.Perhaps the best thing the Chancellor did in his Budget, then, was say “No”.To almost all of it. For an hour or more, I waited for the sting in the tail — the bit where Fiscal Phil turned Hatchet Hammond.But it never came. In paying for his promises — and above all, the NHS — the Chancellor was helped by better-than-expected borrowing forecasts, which showed our economy’s remarkable record of creating jobs is still going strong.But he has also made a calculation that it is better to live with a small and manageable deficit than try to drag the finances back into surplus at the cost of higher taxes. And that voters will see through Labour’s promises to hike borrowing back to stratospheric levels in the name of a socialist transformation of the economy.He decided, in other words, people pay enough tax already.And he’s right. All too often in recent years, it has felt like the answer to every problem — at least from Whitehall’s point of view — is higher taxes and more interference.Hammond was never going to copy his tax-slashing Tory predecessor Nigel Lawson, who made it a point of principle to abolish a dferent tax with every Budget.But at least he drew a line in the sand, deciding it is better when hardworking people get to keep more of their own money.That ending austerity should not, and must not, mean higher tax bills. That hard work should mean hard cash in your pocket.Yes, Hammond — like every Chancellor since Gordon Brown — made too many fiddly little announcements.But he avoided the kind of whacking- great raid on taxpayers’ pockets so many were urging him towards.This doesn’t mean we are out of the woods. Britain’s growth prospects over the next half-decade are still extraordinarily sluggish.The outcome of the Brexit deal will drastically change the fiscal picture.In many ways, Hammond’s speech yesterday was a holding action ahead of the much bigger decisions to come.We still need much more radical action to kickstart growth and productivity. Despite the scale of the housing crisis, for example, there was only tinkering around the edges.But a large part of delivering that growth must involve making the economy more dynamic, more competitive and letting people keep more of their own money as a reward for their efforts — moving the country in the direction outlined by Philip Hammond, rather than the one sketched out by Jeremy Corbyn .The overall verdict on the Budget  The jokes were worse than expected but the numbers were better.More spending on the NHS, tax cuts for millions of voters and the worst ideas kept out of it.Yes, borrowing will be higher — but low enough to keep us out of the danger zone and far, far lower than under a Corbyn government.That is a menu Philip Hammond will be pretty happy with.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: after years of grim penny pinching budgets we must say nice one chancellor
story: Like the bumper tax cut for million workers, a year earlier than promised.The £billion NHS injection, the £billion bailout for defence, hundreds of millions for our pock-marked roads and hard-up schools. Another £.billion to iron out Universal Credit problems. A near five per cent hike in the minimum wage. A big, welcome cut in business rates for struggling firms.New ideas flowed: a levy on web giants’ UK revenues, potentially raising £million, is long overdue — though Philip Hammond must ensure the ­burden does not fall on online shoppers.There was major funding to help councils transform our hollowed-out High Streets, including turning vacant shops into homes. A huge increase in firms’ annual investment allowance will let them deduct from taxable profits up to £million spent on tools and machinery.Heathrow’s e-gates will now speed up entry for visitors from the US, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and Japan as well as Europe — a symbol of a global Britain open for business.Some bad ideas The Sun has criticised, including the proposed “latte levy” on plastic cups, were binned. Duty was frozen again on fuel, as well as beer.Even the OBR’s normally pessimistic forecasts were on Mr Hammond’s side. Growth is predicted to rise steadily, albeit too slowly. Unemployment is set to fall to its lowest in  years.We wish the Chancellor had outlined more radical, visionary low-tax measures. He will need them should Brussels shove us into a no-deal Brexit. But that gripe aside, what was not to like The Tories must not try to ape Corbyn’s £trillion spending fantasy. But it is not “Corbyn-lite” to spend billions fixing Britain’s most pressing problems, evenwe are still running a deficit.As for Corbyn himself, it was obvious he took in barely a word of the Budget.In his “response” he merely recited his normal scripted complaints, flubbing his words and shouting randomly, as is now traditional. He somehow contrives to make even this chaotic Government look like a model of competence.Budgets often unravel when acres of small print are finally scrutinised.But for now... nice one, Chancellor.ANGELA Merkel is a once-brilliant politician scuppered by an arrogant disregard for voters.For years she was admired worldwide. Then she flooded Germany with a million migrants, enraging the public, fuelling extremism and sealing her own downfall.Don’t expect Brussels to learn from it.Their contempt for citizens is even worse. title: boy crystal meth seizure halloween galion ohio
story: Braylen Carwell, from Galion, Ohio, began shaking when he ed from collecting candy on Sunday and was rushed to hospital.While it was initially thought his sweets has been tainted with meth, the boy insists the only thing he put in his mouth before the seizure was a pair of plastic vampire teeth.Police have sent the novelty dentures, which he was given while out trick-or-treating, away to be tested.Investigators also retrieved the sweets which Braylen had been given and collected them as evidence after his parents had thrown them out.His mother Julia Pence described the moment her son began having a seizure.She told Fox : “The left side of his face was just droopy and then he fell and then he couldn’t move his left arm.“And he didn’t know where he was, he didn’t know what he was doing.”Julia says the little boy is still feeling the effects from the powerful drug.She said: “You can tell he is still coming down from it because one minute he is all hyper and the next minute he is tired.The distraught mother admitted to cops that she and the boy’s father are recovering drug addicts, reports TV.But she insists they have both been sober for sometime and strongly denied having anything to do with Braylen’s positive drugs test.She said: “Im not covering up the truth. Im just speaking the truth of what happened to my son, yesterday.“Nobody in my family ordads family would drug my children.The five-year-old’s dad said hed taken his kids trick-or-treating for about two hours on Sunday afternoon.He said his son had only had a couple of pieces of candy and was playing with some sort of fake teeth, according to police.Police Chief Brian Saterfield said: “Right now, there’s nothing specic. title: photos streets britain colourful crazy side life blighty
story: Paramedic Chris Porsz walked hundreds of miles around  cities since  taking quirky pictures of everyday le, from pensioners and party-goers to buskers to bikers.The -year-old from Peterborough has now published a book, Streets Of Britain, featuring more than  pictures from UK cities.The photos offer a unique snapshot of le in Britain today, with pictures of people singing, screaming and scooting.Chris said: I have walked many miles over the years, unsure exactly what I am looking for but I just know when I see it and then snap!.Its usually something surreal, bizarre, someone a bit eccentric who stands out from the madding crowd or everyday people caught up in some humorous interaction.Chris caught the photography bug after buying a camera when his first child Simon was born in .He began walking the streets of his home town of Peterborough for inspiration and quickly developed a passion for street photography. He later decided to hone his craft by visiting other cities.Chris said: Some cities were full of characters, such as Brighton, and it was easy to get lots of good pictures, but others I had to keep ing to until I got what I needed. Ive tried to capture a snapshot of a day in each of the cities.He added that sometimes it would be frustratingsomeone walked in front of the camera at the wrong time or he missed the moment, but other pictures would then make up for it.He added: My near misses would fill another book, but any moments of dejection and self-doubt are soon forgotten when I see a man in Newcastle wearing a pink suit and a horses head, or a pensioner walking around Nottingham with an owl on his arm, as you do.I cannot resist snapping the drunken hens and their inevitable here I am, tadar! pose. Every town too has its fire and brimstone brigade so I just wait patiently for a sinner to come along to make a lucky juxtaposition.Chris said his work as a paramedic at Peterborough City Hospital helped with his street photography as he was able to reassure complete strangers and react instinctively to the unexpected.Sometimes Chris would talk to the subjects of his photos and discover an even more exciting story - the front cover of his book is one of his favourites.He explained: The lady was about  and lived in Peterborough and was describing how as a young girl on Bonfire Night she set off a rocket and it went through the window of a policemans house and burnt it down.Although it looks like she is giving the finger, she is actually putting her finger up to demonstrate the rocket going in the air.

title: mum in tears after universal credit blunder leaves her with 74p to live on for a week
story: Melissa Whitchurch, , and her partner Chris Steer,  desperately rummaged around their home looking for things to sell so that they could buy food for their five-year-old daughter Cheyenne - because of a late payment of their benefits.The couple, from Brighton, were expecting a Universal Credit payment of £ to be paid into their bank account last week and planned their finances around it.But when Melissa went to take out the money, she was horried to see her balance was just  pence and called the Department for Work and Pensionshotline for help.Melissa claimed the officer said the payment was not due for another six days and, when she tried to explain the mistake, told her it was her problem and hung up.Melissa said: All that was going through my mind was how am I going to feed my daughter and send her to school without her snacks She went on: It breaks my heart to think of her feeling like the odd one out, sat there watching everybody  eat their fruit when she doesnt have any.Melissa, who is signed off work due to mobility problems, had originally asked the DWP to change her payment schedule from a monthly arrangement to a fortnightly one.The family received a payment of £ and were told the other half of that would appear two weeks later.They used the cash to pay off bills and get them food to last the next few weeks, but the other half didnt arrive.Shes just one of many Brits who have had problems with the new benefits system, Universal Credit, which rolls six payments into one.Yesterday the Chancellor revealed that Brits will be able to get more help moving onto Universal Credit - but those changes won’t come in until .Former shop assistant Melissa, who has to take  tablets a day for her health, said: Me and my partner can go without, but not our little girl.If we were told this in the first place, we would have budgeted for it.Its horrible. Cheyenne is really sweet about it and she doesnt really understand, thank goodness.We try to keep her away from it.But when she sees Im upset, she will come over and cuddle me and say its okay mummy. Its horrible and the people that are supposed to help just dont care.They are heartless.And she avoided going to the food bank for help because she was expecting to be paid on time.Kind strangers and neighbours have been helping her out with food in the meantime.Partner Chris was also signed off work as a chef for mental health reasons.A DWP spokesperson said: The vast majority of claimants are paid in full and on time, and are comfortable managing their money. Advance payments and budgeting support is available for anyone who needs extra help.Universal Creditreplaces an out-of-date, complex benefits system with clf edges that disincentivised work and often trapped people in unemployment. Under UC, evidence shows people are moving into work faster and staying in work longer.

title: worlds most extreme haunted house where guests are waterboarded has up to 500 people a day apply to take part over halloween
story: McKamey Manor is run by Russ McKamey in San Diego, Calornia, where a few participants every day are bound, slapped and even compelled to eat their own vomit.Guests are put through a worlds scariestThough he says he’s invested more than half a million dollars into the event, animal lover McKamey doesnt ask his guests for any money – just a dog food donation for Operation Greyhound.He told Fox News: It really is like watching somebody live their own horror movie right there, six inches in front of their face.”While no one was ever lasted the full eight hours, McKamey says that in  the record holder, known as Sarah P, lasted six hours inside the house before giving up.Some of its most extreme moments occur on a morgue table, including the use of a live title: the amazing story of how bluetooth got its name and it goes back centuries
story: But even though we all use it and know the technology product as a household name, where does the name Bluetooth come from It turns out the term actually comes from centuries ago - from King Harald Bluetooth who united Denmark and Norway in the th century.His nickname Bluetooth was deemed appropriate for the new piece of technology back in the s due to King Harald having brought two nations together - as the technology was designed to do with electronic devices.Bluetooth enables information and data to be passed from one electronic device to another at short range without a physical connection.The reason for King Haralds unusual nickname was that he had a dead tooth which was a dark blue grey colour.Initially Bluetooth was intended to be an internal code name while the technology was being fully developed, but when the other options pitched by the marketing team were either too unoriginal or couldnt be be patented in time for the release date, they settled with what they had.The Bluetooth logo is a combination of King Haralds initials in rune: ᚼand ᛒ .Susie Dent, Countdowns woman in Dictionary Corner, tweeted this fact earlier today and excited fans with the revelation.She writes: This will be familiar to many, but I love the fact that Bluetooth technology owes its name to a th century ruler - one King Harald Bluetooth, who united Denmark and Norway. His nickname was thought appropriate for technology that brings devices together.Others contributed their own knowledge about the subject, one writing: Harald Gormsson, or Harald Bluetooth, lived in the th century and introduced Christianity to Denmark and ruled over what is now Denmark, northern Germany, southern Sweden and parts of Norway. His nickname came from the fact he had a dead tooth that looked bluish.Others joked about the reliability of Bluetooth: Did King Harald also have pairing problems: unable to pair when too far and pairing with random devices when too close.While one Twitter user joked about an alternative name for Brexit: And one day, through back construction, the Shambles York will be rembered as being named to commemorate Brexit.

title: can you spot the venomous snake hidden in this familys garden
story: The person panicked and thought they saw a brown snake lurking near their garage in Queensland, Australia, so phoned for help.Christian Andersen, who works for local firm South Burnett Snake Catchers  , was called out and confirmed it was a venomous yellow faced whip snake.But he has also issued a warning after an image appeared to show the snake tucked underneath rocks and a small bridge in the garden.This particular species is dubbed the “cheetahs of the snake world” because they can move at lightning speed.They are often mistaken from brown snakes which can be deadly because of their venom.But he also highlighted how discreet they can be because he said the snake is not obvious to see with the naked eye.Christian told Yahoo: “It was a yellow faced whip snake going just by the scales alone.“Their venom isnt considered to be dangerous to humans. story: In a car crash Commons Committee appearance, Caroline Nokes admitted it would be an “almost impossible” job for employers.But she said a No Deal would see firms charged with checking the immigration status of any EU workers – to see which ones were likely to be given ‘settled status’ in Brexit Britain and those who could be turned away.It leaves open the possibility of employers facing jail terms or huge fines because of they have hired the wrong EU citizen.Challenged what immigration rules could be in place to help companies copethe UK crashes out of the EU on March , Ms Nokes said she didn’t know and would write to MPs with the information.She told the Committee: “There’s going to be a dficulty to dferentiate between those who have been and not gone through the settlement process and those who have come as a visitor and then seek to work.”The comments left Labour’s Yvette Cooper – head of the Home Affairs Select Committee grilling the Minister – with her head in her hands. Other MPs branded it a “complete shambles”.Under current plans, EU nationals living in the UK will have until  to apply for ‘settled status’ – permanent residence in Brexit Britain. The hope was they could use a post-Brexit transition period to apply.But Ms Nokes admitted new controls could kick in from March  in the event of a No Deal – leaving new arrivals unsure of their status.So far just , of an estimated . million EU nationals have applied for settled status.Sources told The Sun last night that part of the problem is the Government has yet to work out what the rules for EU nationals arriving after a No Deal will be.Labour’s Stephen Doughty said he feared another Windrush scandal - which saw citizens from Commonwealth countries deported as they couldn’t prove they had right to stay.“I can just see it happening all over again,” Mr Doughty said.“It’s all very well talking about how it’s going to work in theory.“Butthey don’t have the right information I can just imagine a million dferent incorrect decisions being made purely because people don’t have the right documentation of clarity on what is being expected.The British Chambers of Commerce urged the Home Office to make some decisions.Mike Spicer, the lobby group’s head of research, said: “We’ve raised this as a source of serious concern for business communities given the shortening timeframe.“Business can’t plan on the basis of warm words they need to see written in black and white directions from the government about how exactly this scheme will operateno deal is reached.”Erna Solberg said the UK temporarily joining the European Free Trade Association would be a “bit dficult” to accept.It would have kept Britain in the single market while a free trade agreement is thrashed out.Norway, Iceland, Switzerland and Liechtenstein are in it. story: John Downey, , did not attend an historic first hearing at London’s High Court yesterday and was not even represented.But lawyers for the victims’ families were told a trial to hear their civil claim against the IRA man was now set for October .It will seek to prove once and for all that Downey was behind the  central London atrocity which killed four Household Cavalry soldiers at a military ceremony.Andthey win, Downey could be forced to hand over tens of thousands of pounds in damages.News of the trial, which will be heard before a High Court judge, is a landmark moment in the Hyde Park Justice Campaign staunchly backed by The Sun.The campaign was refused help from the Legal Aid Agency to fund the case five times before our readers raised £,.Under huge pressure, the LAA finally caved in — paving the way for yesterday’s hearing before Master Richard Davison.The case is the first major move against Downey since his Old Bailey criminal trial collapsed in . title: brussels to let brit banks keep eu business even if theres a no deal brexit
story: Top eurocrat Valdis Dombrovskis said he will stitch together an emergency pact with the UK to keep the financial services trade stable.The Latvian, who is in charge of the bloc’s financial stability, made the remarks amid warnings a UK crash out could cause a eurozone meltdown.Last month, a banking boss warned a no deal Brexit presented “an immediate and signicant threat to financial stability” in the EU.Catherine McGuinness, the Policy Chairman at the City of London Corporation, urged Brussels to “reciprocate” British efforts to minimise disruption.Britain’s banks are a vital source of funding for the continent and service the vast majority of the lucrative clearing trade in euros.Mr Dombrovskis said stop gap measures would mean UK companies could still service the bloc’s multi-trillion pound derivatives markets after March .He told the Financial Times he “address financial stability risks arising from an exit without a deal”.But he stressed that any sticking plaster would be applied “under strict conditionality and with limited duration”.The PM has previously urged Brussels to consider a series of mini deals to address potential disruption arising from a no deal Brexit. But eurocrats have up until now dismissed her calls over fears that public planning would encourage hardline eurosceptic MPs pushing for a crash out.EU bosses have warned that the UK’s banks will lose much of their access to the Single Market, including key “passporting rights”, after we leave. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Small print revealed that while the tax allowance for higher rate payers will jump from £, to £, a year, they will also have to pay more National Insurance.It means that rather than pocketing an extra £ a year, those on more than £, a year will only see an estimated £ boost.Philip Hammond didn’t mention the National Insurance increase in his marathon Budget speech in the Commons.Royal London policy chief Steve Webb said: “For many people this will wipe out half of the gains from the tax cut.
