title: meghan markle fan instagram new zealand
story: The Duchess of Sussex was doing a public walkabout at the Viaduct Harbour in Auckland when she recognised -year-old Hannah Sergel on Tuesday.Cameras captured the moment Meghans jaw visibly dropped as she mouthed Oh my God and made her way over to give the shaking student a hug.The pair were friends on Instagram before the Duchess deleted her account following her engagement to Prince Harry - but had never met in person.Before deactivating her social media page, the -year-old would send Hannah motivational messages encouraging her to be herself and do well at university.Meghan, who is pregnant with her first child, even sent her a video clip in  personally thanking her for her support and telling her she hoped to meet her soon.And that moment finally happened on Tuesday as Hannah, who had flown across the country, stood with thousands of Royal fans hoping to catch a glimpse of the newlyweds.She was holding a sign that said: Its Hannah from Instagram, when the former Suits star noticed her.Hannah told New Zealands  News: “She said ‘thank you for getting in touch,’ and then she gave me a hug and said she would read my letter that I gave her.“I was friends with her on Instagram before she had to deactivate her account. We used to have conversations and stuff on there. She would tell me to do well at university and encourage me to be myself.”Hannah, who was shaky and flustered during their brief encounter, added that it “means the world” to her that Meghan had recognised her.She told Honey: She recognised me and knew who I was so thats why she came over.She gave me a hug which was incredible - when I first saw her I cried. Shes just such an incredible person and Im just so glad shes happy with Harry.The student was even comforted by New Zealand prime minister Jacinda Ardern afterwards because she had started crying and was such a mess.Incredibly, the politician later sent her a direct message on Twitter with a photo of the special moment.Recounting how she finally met her idol with her followers, Hannah said: Can you believe Meghan Markle held me with both her hands then went in for a hug. Im still in shock.Meghan said come here before hugging me.Hannah was a fan long before the Duchess even met Harry and co-founded the Meghan Markle Daily Twitter account in .It was the penultimate day of the Royal couples marathon -day tour of Australia, Fiji, Tonga and New Zealand.

title: bbc sport dan roan off air leicester city owner
story: Dan Roan was caught questioning Vichai Srivaddhanaprabhas relationship with his PA and ex-Miss Thai Universe runner-up after they were killed in a helicopter crash.The recording was picked up on a Sky News live feed streaming on YouTube from outside Leicester FCs King Power Stadium, where the helicopter crashed on Saturday.He later tweeted to apologise for the comments made on Monday, but was notably absent from the BBCs coverage of the tragedy in Leicester the next day.The corporation has refused to confirm whether Roan would face disciplinary action, saying: “We deal with staff matters privately.”A BBC spokesperson said: “This was an ill-judged comment made in a private off-air conversation for which Dan has apologised.”But a source told the : “The BBC have taken a dim view of this. They told him at the outset that the main thing he needed to do was to strike the right tone, and then this happens.”Roan was standing just yards from the crash site where thousands had come to lay flowers, including Vicahi’s we Aimon and son Aiyawatt, when he made the comment about Nursara Suknamai, who was also killed in the crash.He was overheard saying: The mistress who died in the crash… otherwise known as a member of staff…i.e. mistress.“If you were a billionaire, it’s relatively expected, so we shouldn’t judge.”The recording was later posted online and hundreds of football fans slammed Roan’s remarks.One wrote: It doesnt matter that it was private, or off-air, you were stood  yards away from his memorial.So disrespectful, so thoughtless and hurtful.On Monday afternoon Roan tweeted: “Just want to say sorry for some comments made in a private, off-air conversation earlier with a colleague. Absolutely no offence intended.But his apology was met with backlash from fans who called for him to resign.One supported described the remarks as thoughtless and hurtful, while another said: If you had an iota of contrition, you would tender your resignation.Roan, from Northampton, has been the sports editor for the BBC since September .He joined the corporation in the s and has previously held the roles of Chief Sports Correspondent and Sports News Correspondent.Roan was given an honorary degree by the University of Northampton in July this year.Tributes flooded in for Mr Srivaddhanaprabha and the other victims of the horror crash following Saturday’s match against West Ham United.Police confirmed the others who died were employees Nursara Suknamai and Kaveporn Punpare, pilot Eric Swaffer and his partner Izabela Roza Lechowicz, who was also a professional pilot.It comes as Leicester City players joined Vichais family in paying a tearful tribute to the club owner on Monday.Players - including striker Jamie Vardy and goalkeeper Kasper Schmeichel - held back tears as they stood by Vichais son Aiyawatt at the memorial.Aiyawatt wept as he lay a floral tribute today among of a sea of wreaths and well-wishes left by fans of the club, joined by Vichais sobbing we.

title: swim england apology women jiggly bellies bikini
story: A section on Swim Englands website included guidelines on how female swimmers shouldnt squeeze into swimsuits - while women with boyish figures were advised to try push-up cups to enhance their figures.Simone Webb, a PhD student in gender studies,  said she had been thinking of getting back into swimming and had gone to Swim Englands website to find out more.Instead she found a series of outdated tips on what women should apparently aspire to look like in the pool.She tweeted: @Swim_England apparently think that a boyish body needs to be feminized, that fat women must minimize their bodies, that women wanting to take up swimming should be concerned with their bodily appearance rather than the enjoyment of their sport.Some of the advice included snippets such as: Bikinis totally expose a jiggly belly, and trying to squeeze into a one-piece will not slim your stomach, only emphasize it.The author also thought to add their thoughts on the pear body shape, writing: A pear shape has often been the plague of women, but it no longer needs to be so.Ms Webb added: I feel like Ive become pretty jaded and seen-it-all regarding sexism, but this has genuinely shocked me.Swim England has since removed the article and apologised, saying it contained old information.A spokesperson told BBC Sport: This was an old web page from  that does not represent the views of Swim England. As soon as the article was brought to our attention we removed the page and are in the process of replacing it with more appropriate information.Swimming is one of the most accessible activities for people of all ages and abilities. We want everyone to feel comfortable in the water so they can take advantage of the many benefits swimming has to offer.We apologise for any offence this old information may have caused and hope this wont deter people from continuing to enjoy the water.

title: baby faced car thief mowed down cop pictured rolls royce
story: Kash Parkinson, , could barely see over the steering wheel of the Phantom supercar which was parked in a modest terraced street near his home.Residents reported Parkinson for repeated car and motorbike thefts and he was also arrested for drugs offences, assault vandalism and even terrorising his own grandmother.JPs placed him on youth rehabilitation schemes and also banned him from his regular haunts and associating with other yobs.However Parkinson simply ignored a two year Criminal Behaviour Order - even booking taxis to meet his cronies.When he was placed in a care home away from his long suffering family he threatened to shoot and stab his care workers.The young thug would also post pictures of himself smoking suspicious-looking cigarettes on social media and he even spelt his own name in cannabis leaves.Today Parkinson, from Ashton-under-Lyne in Tameside, Greater Manchester, was starting four years in jail after he mowed down and injured a hero policeman trying to detain him over a mph pursuit.It emerged the teenager was bail at the time over another police chase in a dferent stolen car.At Minshull Street Crown Court, Manchester, CCTV was played of the police pursuit in which Parkinson tried to shake off a patrol at speeds of over mph in a stolen Ford Fiesta which he had fitted with  plates.During the three minute chase on June  this year, Parkinson is seen to drive on the wrong side side of a dual carriageway at .am before ramming into an oncoming HGV.PC Christopher Haxby who was in pursuit jumped out and tried to grab Parkinson but the teenager reversed the Fiesta and propelled the officer backwards into the bonnet of the police car.Despite his head hitting the windscreen PC Haxby bravely got back to his feet and managed to open the Fiesta door and drew his Taser to detain Parkinson.The officer suffered with whiplash and back pain and has been forced to take time off work. Cost of damage to the police car, Ford Fiesta and the HGV was estimated at a total of £,.In the earlier incident Parkinson and a group of friends stole a disabled mans Renault Scenic along with his disability scooter which was in the boot.Police chased him again and blocked in the stolen car in a suburban street where children were playing but Parkinson drove up onto the pavement, narrowly missing a child, before driving off at speed and losing the officers.The Renault was found days later completely written off, and the disability scooter was also damaged to the stage it was deemed ‘redundant’.In court Parkinson yawned and stretched his arms over-dramatically as he listened to the proceedings. He admitted assault occasioning actual bodily harm, aggravated vehicle taking, dangerous driving, driving whilst disqualied and twice breaching a criminal behaviour.Judge Mark Savill told him: “You have shown a lack of respect for the police and a lack of remorse and you have expressed no desire to change. So I must put the protection of the public and a punishment for you first.”He added: Youre just  but have an appalling record and and the footage of the pursuit I have seen is truly chilling. Many people have the good sense to lie when they say they want to change their ways, but you have no idea.“That police officer could have been killed because of your selfishness. It is a wonder how you didn’t kill or seriously injure a member of the public or a police officer.“Your pre sentence report makes a depressing read. I know you have dficulties in your le but you have indicated a lack of remorse and have expressed no desire to change.“You present a high risk of reoffending.“I am not going to impose a sentence that will crush any hope you have - but you cannot reoffend like this.”Parkinson was also disqualied from driving for five years. He has a large number of previous convictions starting from when he was just  for offences including vehicle crime, dishonesty, assaults on a police and public disorder offences.His lawyer Mark Fireman said in mitigation: “This is somebody who has had one of the worst starts in le.“He has been left with many dficulties. He is physically immature, and emotionally extremely immature. He has been in care for many years. He has had minimal parental input.He is essentially bringing himself up.When one does that outside the control from an older person, the sense of what is right and wrong is extremely blurred.This young mans record is appalling but he just hasn’t grown up yet emotionally.

title: 9 11 mobbed supporters back home freed early
story: Mounir el Motassadeq was sentenced to just  years behind bars for accessory to murder in .He received credit for time served after his initial arrest in  — and was freed shortly before finishing even that stretch to be deported to his homeland.Now twisted El-Motassadeq, , is back in a suburb of Marrakesh where he is living in the family home with his we and children.He was seen meeting old friends as he ed from prayers at his local mosque.El-Motassadeq said he was too busy to speak when approached outside his three-storey semi-detached home.But his sister is said to have replied hamdullah – Arabic for praise be to God - when askedshe was happy he was home.And one neighbour told The Daily Mail: We are very happy.The neighbour added: His family were coming from dferent cities to greet him. They were really happy that he is back. His mum was crying tears of joy. His siblings were really happy.There were reported jubilant scenes with people said to have come from all over Morocco to see him.German courts ruled that he was part of the so-called “Hamburg cell” with ringleader Mohamed Atta and two of the other extremists, and was aware the three planned to hijack and crash planes —not all the details of the plot, which took , lives on Sept. , .However, a federal court overturned that verdict in , largely because of a lack of evidence from al-Qaida suspects in U.S. custody, and sent the case back to Hamburg.After a  retrial, el Motassadeq was again convicted of membership in a terrorist organization that included Atta, al-Shehhi and Jarrah. But he was acquitted of being an accessory to murder after the court ruled it didnt have enough evidence that he knew of the hijackers plot.El Motassadeq was sentenced to seven years in prison at the time, but was freed in early  until his appeal could be heard.Later that year, the federal court reversed the Hamburg courts acquittal of el Motassadeq on the accessory to murder charges, ruling that the evidence showed he knew the plotters planned to hijack and crash planes. It limited the number of counts, however, to the  people killed aboard the airplanes, and the -year sentence was restored.El Motassadeq, who admitted to training at an al Qaeda camp in Afghanistan, helped “watch the attackers’ backs and conceal them” by paying their tuition and rent so they could keep up appearances as students in Germany as they plotted, the court found.He was described as the treasurer for the   hijackers and is one of only two men convicted for Sept. .Zacarias Moussaoui is serving six le sentences in a maximum security prison in the US after admitting to being part of the plot.A version of this story originally appeared on The New York Post.

title: wh smiths 155m us deal sees further shift from uk high street
story: The only purchases made by WH Smith in the s were small in-fill acquisitions such as UNS, an operator of retail outlets and coffee shops in hospitals, for just #m in  and  stores from the failed British Bookshops and Stationers chain in  for a mere #m.So Tuesdays acquisition of InMotion, the US digital accessories retailer, is quite a dramatic step by the standards of this venerable old company.The mdeal represents WH Smiths biggest acquisition for nearly two decades.It is also very much in keeping with WH Smiths strategy.InMotion, based in Jacksonville, Florida, operates  stores across  airports in the US and buying it will double the size of WH Smiths international travel business.While many people assume that WH Smith, founded in , makes most of its money from its traditional high street stores, it is actually its travel business - taking in outlets at airports, railway stations, hospitals and workplaces - that has been the main growth generator in recent years on the back of the boom in air travel.The travel business has grown profits in each of the last  years and now accounts for two-thirds of group operating profit.The importance of the travel arm was shown by the trading update accompanying the deal announcement.During the first eight weeks of WH Smiths financial year, which began on  September, total sales in the travel business were up % on the same period last year and up % on a like-for-like basis .

story: NewsopinionJeremy Corbyn and John McDonnell face some taxing questions: Mirror Politics morning briefingThe Labour leadership is hit with a backlash after refusing to reverse Philip Hammonds tax cutsShareCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politics:,  OCT NewsopinionJohn McDonnell and Jeremy Corbyn have taken a controversial position on tax "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email All politics is about choices. As Nye Bevan once said “the language of priorities is the religion of socialism.” In his Budget on Monday Philip Hammond made clear his priorities and he definitely wasn’t praying at the altar of socialism. When presented with the choice of cutting taxes for the wealthy or helping those on the lowest incomes, he went for the former . Presented with the choice of handing high earners more than pound a year or ending the welfare freeze, he went for the former. Presented with the choice of cutting corporation tax or additional funding for education, the police and local government, he went for the former. Which made it remarkable that John McDonnell yesterday said Labour would not reverse the income tax measures in the Budget even though % of the tax cuts will benefit the top half of earners. Andy Burnham was one of many Labour figures to warn McDonnell’s position would not hold. The Greater Manchester mayor said he could not see how tax cuts for the wealthiest could be the priority when the police were so stretched and there are “people dying on British streets for want of a roof over their head.” Many Labour MPs also voiced concerns. Jess Phillips put it succinctly in a tweet this morning: “When Philip Green gets more from the budget than a midwe might I suggest we are on sh**ty ground.” The Shadow Chancellor, who is meeting business leaders today, is showing a pragmatism that comes with the challenge of seeking power. But you cannot help thinking thata previous Labour leadership had adopted this position he would have been one of the first to object. Even when Hammond made the right choice - the additional funding for the NHS - it fell short of what is required. As the IFS noted yesterday, the lt in NHS spending amounts to an increase of .% a year which is below the average increases of .% a year over the NHS’s entire history and the % a year over the period of the last Labour government.

She had been given special permission by her teacher to be absent and she has to write a journal for her class. And it is going to be quite a story. Clara Levacy had travelled with her family to honour her great-great-grandfather, who is one of the most decorated men in British military history. A hundred years ago on Tuesday, October , Harry Greenwood was fighting in the Battle of the Selle, in France, and was awarded the Victoria Cross for a series of acts of gallantry that many people have said mark him out as a “lunatic”.  Lieutenant Colonel Greenwood was leading the th Battalion of the King’s Own Yorkshire Light Infantry on October ,  in a fierce battle against a battered but determined German army. Many of his men had been killed by a machine gun. Harry got up and, with bullets flying all around him, ran towards the gun post and killed the crew with grenades. Later that day, he again rushed a gun in the same way before leading his men to capture  prisoners and eight machine guns. The following morning he again ran towards Germans firing a machine gun. As the citation for his Victoria Cross put it: “He showed the greatest gallantry ... in the face of heavy fire. His valour was beyond all praise.” Harry is my great-great-uncle and I’ve read a letter in which he says he enjoyed “killing Bosche”. That’s a frightening and incomprehensible thing to read about someone who shares a signicant amount of your DNA. But now that I have read about how he handled himself in the trenches and how he fought so bravely to protect the men with him, I am shyincredibly proud.  Prior to being awarded the VC he had got the MCfor gallantry in  and in July  a DSOfor bravery under fire. In December,  it was announced he was also being awarded a “Bar” to add to his DSO for an occasion when he had fought off two enemy attacks – even after he had been blown up by a shell. As a Lt Col, Harry was one of the most senior ranks in the field – he did not have to stick his head above the trenches or run in front of his men. He could send “boys”, cannon fodder, to do the risky stuff. But not Harry. He ran with his men and ran from the front, and fought with them to protect them as best he could. He had been at war for four years, blown up by shells including friendly fire, been gassed and watched hundreds of his friends killed.  Shortly after the announcement of his VC, Harry wrote: “I did nothing really, save drive on, kill a few huns and cheer our own fellows on a bit when they flagged.” Harry’s brother, David, explained to family that Harry “lacked imagination” – while most people in combat worried about what would happen to themthey ran in front of firing machine guns, Harry was somehow able to block that out of his mind.  He was given his medal by King George V at Buckingham Palace in  and the Daily Mirror published his picture with that of four others awarded the VC that day. The following year he was part of the guard of honour when the Unknown Warrior was laid to rest at Westminster Abbey. In , Harry’s family donated his medals to the Regimental Museum of the King’s Own Yorkshire Light Infantry in Doncaster. In , the Government announced that every VC winner from the First World War born in the UK would be honoured with a paving stone laid in the town of their birth. So that is why I was joined last week by my rd cousin Clara Levacy and  other relatives from the extended Greenwood family in Windsor to mark the shycentenary of Harry’s actions.  If anyone there was in doubt of the signicance of Harry’s achievements, Colonel Dan Reeve of The Rlesspoke to say: “Hiswas an exceptional le that showed a pattern of selfless behaviour in which he routinely placed the interests of others before that of his own.  “He understood that a successful le was not one that pursued self-gratication, but rather one that sought to serve others and build society.” As we watched that paving stone being unveiled by a representative of The Queen and listened as a bugler from The Rles Regiment played Last Post, I read out the names of the  men from Harry’s battalion who died in the two days for which he was awarded the VC.  Among them was the name Harry Greenwood – when I first read it I thought it was a mistake but then I checked. By sad coincidence, on the day one Harry Greenwood got the VC, another Harry Greenwood from the same battalion was killed in action. Private Harry Greenwood was the son of a musician from Wombwell, nearly Barnsley – and he was just . We remembered him as we remembered our Harry. Band of Four Fighting Brothers

title: baby faced teen who posed
story: NewsBaby-faced teen who posed joyriding in Rolls Royce yawns as hes locked up for running over police officerKash Parkinson sent the officer flying onto the bonnet of his stolen car and a court in Manchester heard how he could have been killedShareCommentsByJohn ScheerhoutAmy WalkerDanya Bazaraa:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsKash Parkinson who bragged about his le of joyriding and posed in the drivers seat of a Rolls RoyceLtd"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA baby-faced teen who posed joyriding in a pound, Rolls Royce yawned as he was locked up for reversing into a police officer.Defiant pictures show Kash Parkinson, , shamelessly bragging about his le of joyriding from the drivers seat of the luxury Phantom supercar.At ft ins, he was so small he could barely see over the steering wheel of the vehicle which was parked in a modest terraced street near his home in Ashton-under-Lyne, Greater Manchester.He has proved a massive headache for police and locals due to the misery he has brought to his neighbourhood. Parkinson, who has an appalling record amassed since he was just eleven, also posted bragging pictures of himself smoking suspicious looking cigarettes on social media and spelt his own name in cannabis leaves.  Yesterday he began a sentence at a young offenders institution for another string of offences, including reversing a stolen Fiesta into a police officer who was trying to catch him. Parkinson stretched and yawned loudly as he was handed a four-year sentence at Manchesters Minshull Street Crown Court, Manchester Evening News reports.Describing how Parkinson had reversed into the police officer, the judge said: You tried to get past and rammed into the front of the lorry. The very brave police officer, doing what police officers do on behalf of decent members of society, got out and tried to approach you. What did you do  You reversed. The door was open and caught him, sending him flying onto the bonnet of his car. What he must have been wondering at that time one can only imagine. The court heard how the police officer could have been killed. Parkinson had amassed  previous convictions for  crimes from the age of , the court heard.This included twice assaulting police officers as well as robbery, violence, theft of vehicles and flouting court orders. His defence barrister told the court Parkinson had one of the worst starts in le I have seen and is extremely immature for his age. The judge said he accepted what the teenagers barrister said, but added that there comes a time when the public has to be protected. Parkinsons name and face were earlier published on October , , when he was made the subject of a criminal behaviour order which banned him from the Smallshaw estate in Tameside and disqualied him from driving until . The order made little effect.  On May , this year, he stole a specially-adapted Renault Scenic, which carried on board a mobility scooter and was owned by a disabled man. The owner thought he had lost the keys and had called for roadside assistance, but then saw Parkinson and his young male friends get in the car, with the keys, start the engine and drive away. The car was spotted in the Smallshaw estate that night, with residents reporting a car was screaming around the streets while children were out playing, prosecutor Jon Close told the court. Police patrols gave chase but the stolen Scenic mounted the pavement, narrowly missed a child and sped away, the judge heard. Patrols managed to stop the badly damaged car after it was spotted being driven recklessly again, but the occupants fled.  The car had to be written off and the mobility scooter was also damaged. Parkinson was arrested, charged and appeared before magistrates who released him on bail on June  - a decision described as astonishing by the judge because of his appalling criminal record. It was while on bail - and also on licence for another crime - he went on to commit more and worse crimes. Within three weeks of being released, on June , Parkinson was spotted at the wheel of a stolen Ford Fiesta which he drove at speeds topping mph around Tameside in an attempt to escape the law. The pursuit was captured by a dash camera mounted in the pursuing police car and the footage was played in court. It showed the Fiesta speeding in Ashton-under-Lyne but being forced to stop because a civic-minded HGV driver, who was coming from the opposite direction, used his vehicle to block any escape. PC Christopher Haxby is seen getting out of his patrol car to arrest the driver but Parkinson simply reverses, smashing the open door of the Fiesta into the officer, propelling the bobby onto the bonnet of his own vehicle.  The brave cop is seen to pick himself up, draw his Taser stun gun and order the occupants from the vehicle. He is heard shouting: Get out! Get on the f***ing floor now. Parkinson ran away but was arrested after a brief foot-chase, although he tried to claim during his police interview that he had not been the driver of the Fiesta. The damage caused to the police patrol car was estimated at pound,, while the stolen Fiesta required repairs costing pound,. The HGV had been damaged to the tune of pound,. PC Haxby suffered whiplash as well as injuries to his right leg and shoulder. He could have been killed, noted Judge Martin Savill. After brief details of Parkinsons criminal record were read out, the judge went on: That to me sums up this young mans approach to le. He couldnt care less. He associated with children rather than youths his own age, the court heard. The report describes him as effectively bringing himself up, said Mr Fireman.  Addressing the defendant, who appeared in court via video-link, Judge Savill said he accepted what the barrister said but added that there comes a time when the public has to be protected. This young mans record for one his age is so that it passes beyond the bounds of appalling, said Mr Fireman, while the judge noted that the defendant had unashamedly told probation workers he was unwilling to change. A judge slammed Parkinsons quite appalling criminal record. He sent Parkinson to a young offenders institution for four years and disqualied him from driving for five years. I can only hope this will offer you some cause to consider where your le is going, Judge Savill told him. But Parkinson appeared unconcerned, stretching and yawning loudly as the sentencing hearing drew to a close. How long did I get  How long gets taken off forremand and that  he asked an unseen official in the room at a detention centre where he is being held. Parkinson, of Ashton-under-Lyne, had pleaded guilty to two counts of disqualied driving, two counts of dangerous driving, twice breaching his criminal behaviour order, aggravated vehicle taking, assault causing actual bodily harm and driving without insurance.

story: NewsHow going vegan can signicantly improve mental health, reduce diabetes and lower weightPeople on plant-based diets in six of the trials were able to cut down or stop taking diabetes drugs and lost nearly twice as much weight as othersShareCommentsByMartin BagotHealth and Science Correspondent:,  OCT News“Depressive mental health symptoms” had improved “signicantly” in vegan groups covered by the studies "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailGoing vegan could help stave off mental health problems, research reveals. Plant-based diets can boost mood, lower weight and reduce type  diabetes rates, the study of  clinical trials indicated. “Depressive mental health symptoms” had improved “signicantly” in vegan groups covered by the studies, Experts at City, University of London found. Lead author Anastasios Toumpanakis said: “It can be concluded plant-based diets accompanied by education can signicantly improve psychological health.” People on plant-based diets in six of the trials were able to cut down or stop taking diabetes drugs and lost nearly twice as much weight as others.  Diabetes expert Dr Katarina Kos, of Exeter University, said: “The success was probably down to the fact a vegan diet tends to be low in calories and low in fat.” The clinical trials included  people mostly in their mid s, lasted for  weeks on average and were run between  and .

title: man says universal credit left
story: NewsUniversal Credit left me homeless - I had to steal sandwiches to surviveJordan Davidson, , says he was receiving £ a fortnight in Employment and Support Allowance at the start of the year before switching to Universal creditShareCommentsByAlex GroveAbigail OLeary:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsJordan says he has resorted to food banks and even stealing sandwiches to survive "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man claims Universal Credit left him homeless and forced to steal sandwiches to survive. Jordan Davidson, , says he was receiving pound a fortnight in Employment and Support Allowance at the start of the year before switching to Universal credit. He know receives just pound a month after claiming advances in payments at the start of his switch during a stint at a hostel in Birmingham. Jordan now says for the next fortnight he will have no money in his bank, forcing him to rely on soup kitchens and food banks, reports Hull Live. Speaking about how he survives on so little money, Jordan said: I’m just really starting to feel it now and it has been a mess since I started my claim.  “I was working but now I’ve got another two and a half weeks to go with not a penny in my bank account – and I’m not coping. “I’m not able to afford food and when I say I’ve got nothing, I mean I’ve got nothing. I’ve had to resort to begging, I’ve been homeless and I’ve had to steal sandwiches because I’ve had nothing when I’ve been at my lowest.” Jordan says he has no relationships with any of his family and was moved into foster care at the age of . He moved to Birmingham for a fresh start but was hit hard when he was forced to make the switch to Universal Credit sooner than he would have had to had he stayed in Hull. He managed to bag himself two jobs between April and September but when seasonal work at Haven in Flamborough came to an end he once again found himself homeless. Mr Davidson moved in with a relative in Hull, but after a huge bust-up he realised he had nowhere to turn until he was helped by Carl Simpson, founder of Raise The Roof Hull Homeless Project.  Mr Davidson said: “I couldn’t find a job that could accommodate my housing needs but now I’m living in a house share off Beverley Road which has been arranged by Carl.” Mr Simpson has also given Mr Davidson a job in his cafeacute in English Street, west Hull, but the struggling -year-old admits he still struggles with depression. “There has been some pretty low points for me this year,” Mr Davidson said. “I’ve been on my own and sat in a pub with nothing of my own to my name and nowhere to get money from. “I’ve got this new house that I want to make homely but I’ve got no money to be able to do that and I do get depressed from just being in my room. “I feel depressed all the time but I’ve had to keep telling myself I can’t let it bother me because otherwise things will all go downhill. Mr Davidson, who also worked at Hull Fair this year to gain some extra income, said during the period when he was in employment, the money he used to receive in Universal Credit was still deducted from his monthly wage because of the advances he had had. He thinks the controversial new benefits payment, which was created in a bid to streamline the system and replace six working age benefits, does not help claimants like him.  “The government are not looking at the reality of Universal Credit and how it can affect people. I don’t know others who have suffered in Hull because it hasn’t been fully rolled out here yet but it has hit people hard in places like Birmingham. “No one knows what they are doing,they should be doing this or that and what they should be getting. If the government could walk a day in anyone’s shoes on this benefit then you would see the pain it causes. It is just wrong.” There is a standard five-week wait for the first payment when you start claiming Universal Credit and Hull’s Britannia House is one of the final  Jobcentres in the country which is not launching the payment until November and December. Therefore, fears are growing in the city asyou start claiming at the end of November or midway through December, it is unlikely you will get your first payment before the New Year. Mr Simpson, who was keen to help Mr Davidson after learning about his plight, said: “It’s the gap from between the start of the claim and the payment which is causing problems and people are having to rely on foodbanks and soup kitchens.  “Some landlords are not as patient when it comes to rent and people can end up losing their properties. These people are trying their best to do what they can to better themselves and Jordan Is hard working but has very little support. “We are worried people will get hit hardest around Christmas time which is a time when people are trying to look after their households and just the worst time for this rollout to happen.” While it could not go into Mr Davidson’s specic situation, the DWP said the vast majority of Universal Credit claimants are paid in full time and on time and are also comfortable at managing their money. A spokesman said: “Advance payments and budgeting support is available for anyone who needs extra help. “Universal Creditreplaces an out-of-date, complex benefits system with clf edges that disincentivised work and often trapped people in unemployment. Under UC, evidence shows people are moving into work faster and staying in work longer.

story: NewsMeghan Markle and Prince Harrys Royal Tour - Amazing little moments you might have missed from couples adventureMeghan Markle and Prince Harrys Royal Tour  including lots of official occasions, but there were also some very sweet unplanned moments along the wayShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor:,  OCT NewsIts been a very special tour "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle and Prince Harry certainly made their first Royal Tour one to remember, with -days filled with fun and exciting engagements. Meghan spots old pal in the crowd Hannah Sergel was part of a huge group of fans who waited at Viaduct Harbour in Auckland to catch a glimpse of Harry and Meghan. Her jaw dropped when she realised who was holding it, and she can be heard saying oh my God before rushing over to give her a hug.  Harry reveals adorable name for Meghans bump During a speech at New Zealands stunning Abel Tasman national park, Harry referred his and Meghans little bump to the delight of people at the event and across the world. Harrys touching words to little boy whose mum has passed away During a public walkabout in Auckland, New Zealand, Harry spent several minutes talking to six-year-old Otia Nante who was stood in the crowd with his nan Te Nante, . After learning Otias mum had died when he was one, the -year-old Duke of Sussex told him: Le will always be alright, you know that  I’ve made it to -years-old and le is great. I have a beautul we and a baby on the way. Your le is going to be sorted, don’t you worry about that.

title: parents shock after universal credit
story: NewsParents shock after Universal Credit leaves them with just p to live onThe panic-stricken parents Melissa Whitchurch and Chris Steer say they were told it was "their problem" by the Department for Work and PensionsShareCommentsByLaura Sharman:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics article.ece,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA family-of-three were expected to survive with less than a pound in their bank account for a week after a mistake over their benefits. In a panic, Melissa Whitchurch, , called the Department for Work and Pensions hotline but claim she was that it was her problem. Melissa and her partner Chris Steer were expecting a Universal Credit payment of pound to be paid into their bank account at midnight last Thursday and had budgeted accordingly. However, to the mum-of-ones horror, when she went to draw out the money, her balance was just  pence. Melissa claimed the officer said the payment was not due for another six days and, when she tried to explain the mistake, told her it was her problem and hung up.  The couple resorted to scouring their home to find things they could potentially sell so they could afford to feed their three-year-old daughter, Cheyanne. Melissa, from Brighton, East Sussex, said: All that was going through my mind was how am I going to feed my daughter and send her to school without her snacks  The children all put healthy food in a box at school in the morning, such as fruit and crackers, and then they sit down and eat it together during story time. It breaks my heart to think of her feeling like the odd one out, sat there watching everybody  eat their fruit when she doesnt have any. Melissa had originally asked the DWP to change her payment schedule from a monthly arrangement to a fortnightly one.  When the family received their last payment of pound, they were told the other half would arrive two weeks later and used the money to pay bills and buy food to last a fortnight. But when the second half did not arrive, Melissa was told it would be made on the last day of the month and was forced to wait six days with only  pence to her name. She said: Me and my partner can go without, but not our little girl. If we were told this in the first place, we would have budgeted for it. Its horrible. Cheyenne is really sweet about it and she doesnt really understand, thank goodness. We try to keep her away from it. But when she sees Im upset, she will come over and cuddle me and say its okay mummy. Its horrible and the people that are supposed to help just dont care. They are heartless.  The family have been surviving on food donations from strangers and neighbours who heard about their desperate situation. Have you been affected by Universal Credit  Email webnews@mirror  Melissa said: I could have gone to the food bank last week but since I thought I would be paid the next day, I didnt and the next one isnt for another week. So weve been getting by thanks to the kindness of other people. One lady heard about my situation and came and gave us some bread, milk, ham and cheese and Id never even seen or spoken to her before.  Melissa said she would love nothing more than toto work since she was signed off due to problems with her health  years ago. But the former shop assistant has limited mobility and has aids to help her around the house due to her back pain and other health issues, for which she takes more than  tablets per day.  Chris was also signed off from his job as a chef just five months ago for mental health reasons. Universal Credit is a new benefits system, introduced to simply and replace many existing benefits and tax credits and consists of a single, monthly benefit payment into a bank account. A DWP spokesperson said: “The vast majority of claimants are paid in full and on time, and are comfortable managing their money. Advance payments and budgeting support is available for anyone who needs extra help. “Universal Creditreplaces an out-of-date, complex benefits system with clf edges that disincentivised work and often trapped people in unemployment. Under UC, evidence shows people are moving into work faster and staying in work longer.The Mirror is urging our readers to back our petition to stop the rollout Universal Credit which is plunging families into debt and despair and replace it with a fair system.

title: pride britain human spirit can
story: NewsopinionPride of Britain: Human spirit can overcome greatest hardships - Ellas giggling face is living proof of thatThe winners of our Daily Mirror Pride of Britain Awards never fail to amaze and inspire me with their incredible braveryShareCommentsByAlison PhillipsColumnist:,  OCT NewsopinionLittle Ella Chadwick has spent most of her young le in hospital undergoing dialysis "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTo lose a child to cancer must be entirely shydevastating. But to lose two children to the same cruel disease  How could any parent survive that  It’s impossible to comprehend. And yet Eddie O’Gorman, a quiet, unassuming father and businessman did just that.He and his we Marion, who’s also since died, discovered in one -hour period that their son Paul and daughter Jean had just months to live having been struck down with dferent types of cancer. After their deaths – and with the incredible support of Princess Diana – they set up the charity Children with Cancer which has since raised a shystaggering poundmillion and helped increase the survival rates of children diagnosed with cancer from around % to almost %. This week Eddie was recognised for his work at the Mirror’s Pride of Britain awards.When it’s televised next Tuesday evening I guarantee you too will be overwhelmed by the strength of Eddie to carry on after such a terrible tragedy. For how much heartache could one person be expected to endure   And yet the sense I’m always left with after attending Pride of Britain is that no matter how tough the challenges some people are expected to face in le – the human spirit still proves to be greater. Like little Ella Chadwick who has spent most of her young le in hospital undergoing dialysis,  operations, strokes and two transplants.But not only has she battled back to health, she now spends her spare time making glittery cards and raising money for other poorly kids in hospital. Another winner is Emma Picton-Jones who was widowed with two young children when her husband took his own le. title: callum booth keen to keep feelgood factor going at dundee united
story: Callum Booth is delighted to see everyone associated with Dundee United pulling in the same direction and he’s determined to reward today’s travelling support with more to cheer at Dunfermline.The Tangerines head to East End Park today for new manager Robbie Neilson’s third match in charge.Despite only being in charge for a couple of weeks now, United left-back Booth says the new gaffer has already made quite an impression.He said: “It’s been brilliant, really good. Training has been really good and I thinkyou asked any of the boys in the changing-room we’d all be the same.“It’s really gone up a level, we’re all enjoying it and I think that shows on a Saturday.“It’s been quite tough but I think we needed that. It’s been enjoyable at the same time, though, and we’re all buying into his ideas.”Off the field there seems to be an air of optimism around Tannadice but Booth knows getting results on the pitch is the only way to realise their hopes of promotion.And that means keeping their unbeaten run under the new boss going against a Dunfermline side that have already bagged a deserved win over the Tangerines.Booth added: “Four points from the first two games isn’t too bad but I think they were two good performances as well.“We feel hard done by we didn’t get the win over Inverness – I think most people there would agree with that but it wasn’t to be.“At least we put in a really positive performance and everyone is pulling in the same direction.“There is a good feel about the place and, hopefully, we can kick on now and go on a little run.“The players, coaching staff, fans all seem to be pulling in the same direction especially since the new gaffer has come in.“A thousand fans down at Partick, great backing and then same again last weekend. The fans were right with us until the last minute.“It does help, it makes a massive dference and Dunfermline isn’t too far down the road so I’d expect another good away following.“I think the fans can see the work and effort we’re putting in, evenwe didn’t get the three points last Saturday.“The fans have been great and long may it continue.”Allan Johnston’s Pars have been struggling of late after a lightning fast start to the season saw them follow up four wins from four in the Betfred Cup group stage with an impressive - victory at Tannadice.Since then, Dunfermline have only managed eight points from the following eight games and were beaten - at home last weekend despite dominating against Queen of the South.In fact, scoring goals at home has been a real problem of late with just the two Championship strikes going in.Booth  Co., however, are wary of a repeat show from the Pars.He said: “Dunfermline were really good at Tannadice the first time we played them and thoroughly deserved to win.“I think most people would be surprised they’ve not kicked on from that first game.“They played well that day and deserved the win.“I’ve not seen much of them since but it’s not worked out for them since for whatever reason.“They’ll still be a dangerous opponent, though, because they are, obviously, capable of putting in a performance but have just been a bit inconsistent recently.“If we go about it like we have done in the last two games then we’ll give ourselves a chance.“We’ll be going there in positive spirits, try to take our chances and come back up the road with the three points.”

title: cat returned to dundee family after an incredible five years on the run
story: A Dundee family are over the moon after finding their pet cat in a shelter – five years after he disappeared.Christine Ritchie and her son Charlie were distraught when black and white moggie Curtis went out and never came back after they moved house.The Ritchies moved from the Blackness Road area to Stobswell five years ago, when Curtis was three and a half years old.According to Christine, however, he was not a fan of Stobbie and left to go back to the West End – not just once, but twice.She said: “We kept Curtis indoors for a while and then, when we let him out, he just disappeared.“We got him back and kept him in for a couple of weeks but then he disappeared again and that was it.”The family searched high and low, night after night, after Curtis failed to reappear, and eventually resigned themselves to the fact they might never see him again.Charlie, , was devastated, having looked after the cat since he was born.However, recently there was a surprise on Facebook’s Missing Pets Dundee and Angus page – a cat which looked just like Curtis had been found.The Facebook post read: “Do you recognise ‘Earl’  He is a big black and white boy who was found straying in the Dundee area.“We suspect Earl has been straying for some considerable time, perhaps years.“He is approachable and keen on treats.”Earl was taken in temporarily but later escaped from his foster home, before being taken in by Cats Protection Scotland, which has a shelter on Foundry Lane.Christine and Charlie went in at the weekend to seeEarl was really Curtis.Christine said: “Charlie was as happy as anything, even though Curtis hissed a bit at first, but after a while he settled.“It’s overwhelming to think he was out there for all this time.“My phone’s been ringing non-stop with people wanting to come over and see him. It’s been like finding a long-lost member of the family again.”The Ritchies believe Curtis survived thanks to the kindness of strangers and by fending for scraps but they will never know for certain.Nor will they know how Curtis travelled across Dundee without getting hurt, but the family will be keeping a very close eye on him from now on.Christine added: “Charlie’s been checking on him every  minutes to make sure he doesn’t disappear again.”

title: dundee appoint jimmy boyle as new assistant manager
story: Dundee have appointed Jimmy Boyle as assistant manager to Jim McIntyre.The -year-old steps up from his post as head of the Dark Blues youth academy to team up with the new boss who arrived to succeed Neil McCann last week.Jimmy has been in the dugout for the games against Livingston and Hearts and confirmation he’s to remain their permanently brings to an end the Billy Dodds saga that’s dragged on since the new manager arrived last week.Dodds, who was Jim’s number two at Ross County, was his first choice for the same post at Dens Park, but well documented matters relating to his departure after Dundee went into administration in  made him unacceptable to many Dark Blues fans.As well as him, it’s understood Dens legend Barry Smith and Aberdeen coach Barry Robson were also being considered.But Jim has opted for another man he knows well and who has extensive experience in coaching and management.The pair played together at Airdrie and during eight years with the Diamonds, Jimmy appeared in two Scottish Cup finals.After a career that included spells at a string of clubs including Queen’s Park, Livingston and Partick Thistle, he was Airdrie’s under- coach for several seasons before succeeding Kenny Black as manager in .He was sacked three years later, but was quickly appointed to the SFA’s coaching staff and in  was headhunted by Dundee to take charge of developing their emerging talent.Over the last two-and-half-years he’s transformed the fortunes of the club’s underage sides and last season saw him steer the Development squad to a second place finish in their league.Known for someone who prefers to stay out of the limelight, he has been persuaded to make the step back up to first team level and assist his old team-mate in keeping Dundee in the Premiership.A Dundee FC statement said: #Jimmy has been with the club since joining as head of youth development in . During that period he has overseen the academy while also managing the development side and helping out with the first team.

title: dundee people team of 16 steps out in honour
story: Family and friends raised more than £, for Cancer Research UK in memory of much loved dad and grandad Steven McDonald.Steven was just  when he lost his battle with prostate cancer on February .Just weeks before his death he was enjoying a walk with brother Andy when Steven suggested that the pair take on the Kiltwalk in August.Andy, director at MM Plumbing and Heating Supplies, said: “Steven was just finishing his course of chemo in February and thought he was going to be here for another three years.“We were out walking in Forfar in January and he asked meI would like to do the Dundee Kiltwalk with him to raise money for Cancer Research.“I have always been quite a keen walker but Steven was never really into it, so I was surprised when he suggested it.“I agreed and said I would look into getting both of us signed up.“Sadly, Steven died three weeks later.“It was a massive shock to the whole family, but we thought it was a no brainer to go on with the walk in memory of Steven to try to raise as much money as possible.“I then asked more family members and Steven’s friendsthey would like to join me on the walk.“Steven’s children Kieran, , and Darryl, , also joined us along with my sister Debbie.“In total there were  of us who completed the -mile walk from Tayport to Monieth.“The Kiltwalk was great fun and the weather was kind to us.“Steven was very much a part of the walk and we all kept saying that we thought he was with us every step of the way.“We all met at Steven’s memorial bench in Broughty Ferry where we had scattered his ashes.“We sat and shared memories, reminisced and took a moment to think about him.“We all had a dram as well, even though we weren’t meant to.”Andy is no stranger to fundraising, having already completed two Dundee half marathons for the same charity.Andy added: “I have lost quite a lot of family members to cancer so it has always been a charity close to my heart.“I signed up in January to do the Dundee half marathon again in July, thinking my brother would be at the finish line to see me across the line but unfortunately he wasn’t there.“The funds that we were raising by completing the Kiltwalk were always going to be for Cancer Research UK and through a complete team effort we all managed to raise a grand total of £,.“My customers, staff and suppliers at MM Plumbing  Heating Supplies played a big part in supporting us and helping us getting to the fantastic amount.“The main point of doing this walk was to raise awareness of Cancer Research and to also keep the memory of Steven.“I would like to say thank you again to everyone who has shown their support.”Steven was also the proud grandfather to Kieran’s son, Noah.And daughter Darryl welcomed his grandaughter, Esme, just two days after he died.

story: A city group which works to keep Dundee looking beautul is seeking support to raise more funds.Bonnie Dundee is asking people to vote for it in the Aviva Community Funding Project.A spokesman for the group said: “Bonnie Dundee is a group of volunteers which has been running for more than  years.“We plant and maintain  planters, two garden areas and one large wildflower meadow in and around Dundee city centre.“We work with the council and help submit the city’s yearly entry to Beautul Scotland.“We have a iety of maintenance and improvement costs which, at present, we have no funds for.“Because of the opening of the VA and more visitors coming to our city, we want to look at more colourful, sustainable planting which will have a longer-lasting effect and give us a basic framework to work around.”The spokesman added: “We are extremely passionate about what we do and rely heavily on people supporting our community events.“Our aim is to be able to make the improvements we need so that what we have can last for the future and will be easier to maintain for future volunteers.“We feel our project benefits the wellbeing of city centre le and gives people the chance to make a dference.“We’re asking people to vote for us at community-fund.aviva voting project view -.”

title: local businesses rally to restore vandalised royal marines garden
story: A maintenance firm has helped to restore an Arbroath garden trashed by vandals.Four years ago, former Royal Marine Chic Grant stepped in after Angus Council said it could no longer afford to maintain the flower bed at Infirmary Brae.In a four-month operation Mr Grant moved  tonnes of earth – with some funding and advice from Angus Council – and created a floral tribute to the Royal Marines on the th anniversary of the corps, which included the planting of nine mountain ash trees.However, when Mr Grant arrived at the site to carry out routine maintenance in August, he found all of the trees had been destroyed.Angus Council leader and Arbroath Independent councillor David Fairweather called the incident “disgraceful” and branded those responsible “dimwits”.The incident came to the attention of specialist grounds maintenance firm Tivoli, which decided to help.Hugh Wood, business development manager for the firm, pulled together a -strong taskforce and, in an all-day exercise, planted nine sorbus mountain ash trees, donated by Craigmarloch Nursery, in a symbolic four-five formation in recognition of the close connection between the town and  Commando.Perimeter beech hedges were also cut back, and general tidying and repair works carried out.DAB Fabrications donated metal plaques, each one representing one of the four continents in which  Commando operates. The volunteers were kept fuelled during the day by Royal Marine veterans who set up a field kitchen.Mr Grant said: “I’m extremely grateful to Tivoli and everyone who came along to help.”

title: pete waterman says local nightclub flicks was as good as any club i visited
story: Record label boss and presenter of The Hitman and Her, Pete Waterman, has fondly remembered his trips to Brechin nightclub Flicks both with his pop acts and for the show, with co-host Michaela Strachan.The building that once hosted the cream of the country’s entertainment scene is going up for auction next month.He said: “Flicks was the furthest north we ever went for The Hitman and Her. If I remember rightly, we hosted four times from Flicks and every one was a huge success. But I was up to visit at least twice a year.“It was pretty amazing because we were so far away from anywhere but always found the audience there to be fantastic. There was never any trouble, people throwing drinks or anything. They were there to enjoy themselves.“We were always well looked after by the Flicks management. And we got to do things we wouldn’t normally do in the other places, like visit the local railway, the distillery, and Brechin City FC, where we even played a friendly match.“It was just a great time. Mike, Stuart and Pete were really lovely guys.“They spotted the potential the show had very early on and what it could do for a club. When we went up to Brechin it sent a message that this place was worth going to and gave it that recognition. We had that nightclub culture which started about ’ or ’ and it exploded. Flicks was a big club in a small town. But it was as good as any club I ever visited, anywhere.“Given the size of the town, that was an amazing achievement. It’s just a fantastic success story. I met the best people there, that’s what I remember.“The friendship was great, and the crowd was always up for it.”https:www.eveningtelegraph fp kylie-minogues-random-appearance-at-local-nightclub-being-auctioned-off

title: tay cities deal which could create 15000 jobs in local area set to become a reality after 350m pledge
story: The Tay Cities Deal will be signed off next week following confirmation in the Budget it is being bankrolled with £ million of public funding.Ministers from both governments are expected to “seal the deal” with a heads of terms agreement, with Perth likely to be the location.It is understood the projects that will be financed as part of the economy-boosting package include the Cross Tay Link Road, the International Aviation Academy in Dundee and Perth City Hall.Chancellor Philip Hammond pledged £m for the deal, which is hoped to create , jobs in Dundee, Angus, Perthshire and north-east Fe over a decade.Scotland’s infrastructure secretary Michael Matheson reaffirmed his government’s £m pledge, which was first made last week.Ellis Watson, chairman of the Tay Cities Enterprise Executive , which has helped direct the bid, said the signing of the heads of terms will see TCD “finally turn from dream to reality”.“This announcement will be looked back on as a turning point for our whole region,” he said.The long-awaited deal is designed to turbo-charge the economy with new transport links, business centres, employment schemes, arts investment and tourist attractions.Scottish Secretary David Mundell said the projects will “drive economic growth in Tayside, boosting jobs and prosperity throughout the region”.“I would very much like to be able to sign heads of terms next week,” he said.“Obviously there are a number of parties to this deal, so we have to manage the logistics of that, but I want to seal the deal next week. That is my aspiration and then actually to move on to deliver on the projects.”

title: tom duthie neil mccann tried to change too much too soon at dundee
story: When Neil McCann looks back on his time as Dundee boss he will surely learn several lessons, ones that can stand him in good steadhe s to management.Perhaps the most obvious will be that, whatever your football philosophy, it has to be tapered to suit the resources you have available when it comes to players.McCann’s mantra at Dens was to play passing football at all times and, ultimately, at all costs. That led to too many goals being lost by errors as, at high risk, the ball was played out from the back.It became increasingly clear some of his defenders in particular were not comfortable with this policy but the manager was not for budging and persevered with the style of play he was convinced would, ultimately, bring success.The number of goals it cost made it inevitable what many saw as stubbornness was what cost McCann his job.That is, perhaps, an over-simplication and, now the dust has settled on the former Scotland international’s departure, a more in-depth look throws up other factors.A look at the players he used in his eight Premiership games in charge this term highlights another couple of causes for his downfall.First off, the list of those involved looks too long. In just two-and-a-half months of league football, Dundee fielded  dferent players.Of course, injury and suspension means some of the constant stream of changes were enforced, but others suggest he was never totally sure of what his best line-up was. Given the style of play he wanted, this lack of consistency in selection had to be an issue.Arguably, an even bigger one was that he fell into the rookie manager’s trap of trying to make too many changes too quickly.The Premiership may not be one of the top leagues in Europe but it does have its own unique qualities. One of them, as most new arrivals testy, is the tempo of the play here is more frantic than in many other countries.Even players coming up from England, where the pace is higher than on the continent, usually comment on that.What that means is players from where have to be given time to adjust and, as they do, it’s important they have men around them who are already experienced campaigners in our top ision.A glance down the list of the men used this season suggests there were not enough performers who fitted into that category.Of the  he used, nine were completely new to the league, while eight others had no more than a season’s experience of it.Ironically, the most used who fell into those categories was when  started the solitary win at Hamilton last month but, in the other outings, seven or eight such players were used.That’s not saying these players are not good enough for this level but, as most experienced managers in any league will say, whatever the level of talent, having so many who are not familiar with their surroundings is a risk they wouldn’t be prepared to take.While McCann did bring in vastly-experienced Premiership performer Kenny Miller at the end of the summer transfer window, the loss through injury of Paul McGowan had to be a major blow.And it should not be seen as insignicant that, as he’s scoured the free-agent market since his arrival as manager, new boss Jim McIntyre has paid particular attention to men who know the top flight well.Martin Woods is expected to sign up once he’s proved his fitness, though Celtic on Wednesday may be too early for that. Woods’ old Ross County team-mate from when McIntyre was in charge, Paul Quinn, has also been linked.

title: Ciyt all set to host a spooky spectacular
story: Members of the public have been advised to be wary of an influx of zombies in Inverness this weekend.The living dead are set to visit the Highland capital today and tomorrow as part of the cityrsquos annual Hallowersquoen celebrations.The ZombieNess celebrations will get under way with a "people hunt" tonight, with the zombies due to emerge from the Victorian Market at around pm.That will be followed by a second hunt tomorrow at pm.Organisers are still on the lookout for volunteers who are willing to be transformed into zombies, and all those who are keen to take part are asked to register between pm and .pm tonight or  noon and .pm tomorrow.Both of the hunts are expected to last two hours ndash unless the zombies prove adept at seeking out their prey.A mass zombie dance has been arranged for the immediate aftermath of tonightrsquos event.Participants will be asked to perform to Dead and Gone, a new track by rock group The Dead Daisies.The group are scheduled to headline the first-ever Monstersfest in Inverness on November  and , and the video for their latest track, which already features zombies, has been viewed around one million times on the video-sharing site YouTube.A film showing the Inverness zombies will be shown on both the bandrsquos and Highland Councilrsquos social media channels after the event.After tomorrowrsquos hunt, the focus will switch to Ness Islands, where the Hallowersquoen show will take place.The performance, Nights of the Living Dead, features young performers from across the Highlands, who have also designed many of the scenes in the show.It has been organised by a number of bodies, including Highland Council, Eden Court, Arts in Motion, Limelight Event Services and Fly Agaric.The show invites families to discover what is hiding behind the bushes at the ever-popular Inverness beauty spot.It will begin at .pm tomorrow and runs for approximately two hours, with a second performance scheduled for .pm on Sunday.Councillor Callum Smith, of the Inverness Events and Festivals working group, said: "We are really looking forward to welcoming families to this yearrsquos shows and we cannot wait to see all the children in
